reviewText:
If Magic : The Gathering and Dungeons & Dragons have a child, Card Hunter would be it.

At its core, Card Hunter is a pen and paper RPG with a twist. You play all of your action through cards that obtained from equiping items. So, different items had different cards.

Pro :
1. Free to play with cash to speedup your progress.
2. Excellent Multiplayer with automatic matchmaking, ladder, rewards, etc.
3. Easy to learn, hard to master.
4. Excellent Singleplayer/Coop campaign.

Con :
1. Currently only 3 class and 3 races. Based on D&D mechanic, this is rather small
2. There is no way to gain cash currency for free other than joining guild (Five 5$ redeemable coupon that only guild master decide who gonna get it). You only get what they give it to you while doing tutorial (spend it wisely).
3. Some dungeon are locked with cash currency. While there is no item that cannot be obtained by free players, the locked dungeon guaranteed to get an epic item for the first time completed.

Some tips :
1. Choose your starting party wisely. While you can change it anytime you want, it can be a hassle to level up it again. A popular combination is dwarf warrior, human priest, and elf wizard but I dont recommend it (see tips 2). My personal favourite is elf warrior, human priest and gnome wizard that kinda hard early on. Check the wiki for some insight. http://wiki.cardhuntria.com/wiki/Cardhuntria:Community_portal
2. You get a free multiplayer pack at Renown 5. Try to raise your renown to that level by doing campaign first. The pack is consist of dwarf warior, human priest and elf wizard with reasonable equipment to get you started multiplayer. Multiplayer character is interchangeable with the campaign character, that is why I suggest not to take that character as your starting character because you get it free later. But, recruiting level 1 character is only 10 gold. So do what you seem it fit.
3. A lot of people is asking this, so I gonna write it here. You can start selling your equipment at Renown 7. I dont recommend to sell equipment because you maybe need it sometimes later for the campaign.
4. When you get your pizza, the game make you spend it at that time. Just dont ! Close the client and you get the pizza without spending it. You can spend it later for whatever seems the best for you.

reviewText:
This is essentially a pay to win game.

The tutorial is well done and quickly gets you into the game. The loot is varied and interesting. Which makes you want to play more. But as soon as you get into multiplayer, you quickly realize that you need to pay in order to compete. The prices are steep too. Balance is nigh impossible because of how the game is centered around card drops.

Single player campaigns are a grindfest. Campaigns are well made, and the level design is well thought out. They are fun, interesting, varied and challenging. Unfortunately you need to pay to proceed to higher level campaigns. After buying the campaign you still have to grind, pay to grind. There is a 1 day cool down and wait to for all the campaigns too.

This game has so much potential if it do away with the f2p model and just be a proper paid subscription game. After all there is no way you can survive without paying.

reviewText:
tl;dr: pay to win.

This is a decent concept held down by a pay to win system that undermines strategy and hours spent getting loot. Loot that is trumped by shop gear which costs you hundreds to thousands of gold to buy, but then is sold for 2... 2 gold.

Another annoying feature" is that players quit the game when you're winning and you have to sit there for 2 minutes waiting when it is clear that they aren't coming back.  The game has a 20 minute timer that is laughable. Most players are quick and every now and then you need some time to think
date: but then there are the players that spend what seems like ages trying to make up their mind on how to move... And this is even in the higher ranks where you're supposed to be playing against players who earned their way up in rank. But this could be another side effect of the pay to win mentality of the game.\n\nIt grasps you for a while but then it just stalls at this pay to win ceiling that makes the game hard to enjoy
recommended: then you get the slow players that make you feel like scratching out your eyeballs. 4/10."

reviewText:
Pay to win.

My first multiplayer game at level 6, my opponent made what I thought was a tactical mistake. He rushed in with one warrior against my entire team of three. I realized it wasn't a mistake when he moved 5 times in one turn with that one character, killing my own warrior using abilities and a lightsaber that took half my life in one hit, then jumping away to the control point so I had no chance to even hit him the next turn. Meanwhile I was hitting back with a stick that did 2 points of damage.

It's just not fun to lose, even though I made no mistakes, because my opponent had paid money for cards and gear three times better than my own.

reviewText:
I strongly recommend this free game, it's a high quality cards/strategy game with some RPG elements that offers a lot of content for free.

It's not pay to win, you can pay to get some extra stuff like costumes, more challenges or some loot when you open chests but it doesn't give you any advantage against other players (well, you might collect some useful items a bit faster, that's all). I decided to pay (I got the Basic Edition) after 30 hours of gameplay and not because I need it but because I feel the developers really deserve it for this awesome game and I think I'll keep playing it for many more hours.

Besides the long solo campaign it offers a great multiplayer experience with a simple but effective automatic matching system and a rating that gets updated after each battle. There are also leagues with different game modes.

All in all, a fantastic free game that shouldn't go without notice.

reviewText:
Part of me wants to give this game a recommend, and rate it about 8.0/10.  If you're looking for a good, fun board game/card game/strategy amalgamation, this is a pretty sharp little package.  The script is witty and funny, the gameplay is tight and well-designed, the game looks beautiful in it's simple cartoon style.  What's not to love?

The problem is the way the financial end is set up.  Now, you can play through the single-player campagin and have all the fun you want with multi-player for free... but if you want to play the additional Treasure Hunt add-on content, through the base game and its two expansions, the in-game pricing is $20+$13+13, for a total of $46!  I felt bad about getting so much fun out of this game for free, and was looking to throw the developers some cash.  I also wanted to complete all of the Treasure Hunts and get the achievements for doing so.  But no way in hell am I paying $46 for it.  Somewhere in the neighborhood of $10-$15 sounds about right, and maybe $5-$10 if you could grab it on a Steam sale.

But it won't ever be on a Steam sale, because the prices are all in-game.  The Steam page simply lists it as a free game, without the pricing tiers or the ability to buy it from Steam.

And to be honest, some of the other the achievements are practically an impossibility.  It's pretty rare to get an epic item, and more difficult to get a legendary.  I have a handful of epics after 80 hours game time and maybe 2-5 legendaries.  But to get the hundreds listed as a part of the achievement?  Probably won't ever happen.  Especially if you're not paying a monthly membership fee on top of everything else, which gives you an additional piece of higher level gear with every loot chest.  It's a fun game... but it's not big or deep enough to keep me playing for dozens to hundreds of hours a month as a part of some subscription model.  It certainly doesn't have the scope that World of Warcraft did back in its day.

The devs would have kept me playing longer, and spending some money, if they hadn't made the non-free full version so ridiculousy expensive.

So enjoy the campaign, get what you can out of it, and be done with it.  If you really want to give the devs some money, you can always buy in-game currency to unlock a few of the Treasure Hunts or a couple of extra costume/characters.

UPDATE:  I had originally given this a marginal thumbs down, but just recently changed it to a thumbs up because of the comments from Sgt. Buttersworth [308] below.  It turns out you can get all of the DLC for cheaper than the fees they charge in-game buying them separately as stand alone bundles.  My advice is to check out the game for free.  If you like it, by the time you start hitting the optional add-ins, the thing to do is click on the pizza slices at the top menubar.  Instead of buying the Basic Edition for $20, the AotA Bundle for $13, and the Citadel Bundle for $13, simply buy 690 slices of pizza for $20.

You can then use those 690 slices of pizza (plus the pizza slices you get from playing the free part of the game) to purchase the treasure hunts in bundles at the following rates: 300 for the Basic Edition treasure hunts, 150 for the AotA hunts, and 150 for the Citdel hunts.  This will get you all of the expansion DLC for $20 instead of $46, and you'll still have some extra pizza left for a few costumes.  Certainly not as many as if you'd bought the DLC's separately, but they're all cosmetic & ultimately unnessary imo.  You also won't have access to the one-month Club memberships that will give you extra loot, but those are also not necessary.  If you want to spend the $46, you can, and the difference will be a bunch more figures/costumes, and three months of Club memberships (one month for each of the bundles).

I'd say that $20 is more what the game is worth, and for that price you can pretty much experience everything the game has to offer.  You can always buy the Club memberships later with additional pizza.  80 pizza will get you a week (and if you don't buy anything else, you'll have enough pizza left for a week membership with the 690 you've bought for $20).  After that, it's about 300 pizza per month with pizza priced at 330 slices for $10.

So to sum up... play the free game.  If you like it, buy all of the treasure hunts in pizza bundles after buying 690 slices for $20... which will also afford you a 1-week Club Membership.  After that, $10 will give you a month of Club Membership if you desire to keep it going, with some pizza leftover each month.

Purchasing that way will give you a better deal than buying all of the bundles for cash at a total of $46.

reviewText:
As a game developer, I am very choosy about my games.  I prefer games that require analysis, meaningful choice, a strategic, non-frenetic pace and that offer enough surprises that the outcome is never certain.

Card Hunter is a turn based delight; a success in all of these areas.  It offers deep mechanics, yet is easy to pick up.  It can be as serious or casual as you like and is great to play with your friends or kids.  Co-op is now in and super fun!

Best of all, it is the rarest of unicorns: being truly free to play and NOT pay to win.  I do however encourage you to buy the expansion packs because supporting games and developers like this is the only way we get more games of this caliber.

reviewText:
Okay, after 2,5k hours I guess it's a good time to actually write something for others to consider.

Because I'm here to recommend the game, I'll just start out with what captured me.
- Nostalgia blasts coming even from the GRAPHICS. Literally everything looks like you're in for a D&D session, or some other tabletop RPG. Even the NPCs can strongly resemble some of the nerds from your surrounding!
- Chest-opening addicts, brace yourselves. This game is incredibly generous in terms of giving you loot. Leagues for 50 gold (slightly more than what a Rare Treasure gives you) rewarding you 3 of these (at least) for just... signing in. One-per-day adventure with enhanced loot that's same for everybody (ergo can be found by someone else and everyone will have it in that place), one-per-day adventure with treasures only, this time it's different from person to person, chests with guaranteed rares for MP wins...
- THE COMMUNITY. Good lord, that's one friendly community. I've yet to find less toxic place in the internet. Open chat, greet people, ask questions, have them answered... that's just something amazing.
- The competitiveness of the multiplayer. People think something like Legendaries give you better stuff
date: after all it's a F2P game." Couldn't be more wrong
recommended: in fact 90% of the legendaries are below mediocre. And so
hoursPlayed: people can get to some decent-high ranks playing with items that are RARE at most. And
voteText: as you'll find out if you play the game

votesTotal: Treasure Hunt adventures (items from these can be dropped just by playing and it's as likely to happen as a drop of any other item) and Club Membership (which only gives you +1 item per SP or MP chest
votesFunny: doesn't include league chests and it's another item of the highest rarity the chest gives. Ergo gives you more items
commentsCount:
but not BETTER items.)

So what's the catch?
- Prepare yourself mentally - this game is a card game WITH DICE ROLLS. And it doesn't use Pseudo-random distribution. What does that mean for an average player? You can be on a freaking amazing luck streak

reviewText:
Genre - F2P (with optional paid elements) Fantasy turn based battle game

I have only played single player and my positive review is based on that. I am having problems with queue times of up to 30 minutes, but hope they will fix this issue soon, and will ignore this with my rating.

I am a fan of board games but without a good RPG friend base, I have to turn to computer games to get my fix. This game manages to satisfy my cravings well. You will use three characters throughout (Warrior, Mage and Priest, but no Rogue yet...).

You fight turn based battles as part of a series of quests. You gain loot and items after each victory. As your characters level up, you get to equip more stuff. Each item has a set of cards attached and these are used for each turn based batle. They will move, protect, boost, heal and attack in various ways. As a result you will develop unique characters with their own advantages and disadvantages (some negative traits have to be played).

The game story plays as if you are playing a tabletop RPG (reminding me of the Knights of pen and paper). This works quite nicely and creates a more immersive experience. I wish that pizza girl would stop distracting the DM!

A great game that gives enough enjoyment as F2P to justify you splashing a bit of cash to get extra quests and skins for your toons.

reviewText:
SKIP DOWN TILL YOU DO NOT SEE MY IMAGINARY GUEST FOR QUESTIONS ABOUT THE F2P STUFF.

What I was expectinga casual game that was attempting to jump on the DnD Bandwagon for people afraid of pen-and-paper and its complexity.

I do not think I have been so wrong and so happy with that ever before in my life. I think I need assistance on this review, so let me nab this radish farmer to help me get my thoughts out.

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Wha is dis den?
Card Hunter is a High-Fantasy, Card-based TBS/Pen 'n' Paper RPG.

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Den its' a casual bloke's DnD den? Why are yas playing dis?
Ah, but that is where you are wrong. Yes, it's High-Fantasy, but that is not quite the setting. You are a guest in the home of Gary and Melvin. Gary is a beginning Game Master (GM), and Melvin is the assholish, but veteran, GM. Gary is the one hosting this game and running the singleplayer (according to my playtime spanning across two days), while Melvin is the prime definition of a neckbeard that needs to remember that games are supposed to be fun.

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Roight, so it's not a standed computa game. How does it play?
Good Question, my Linen-garbed friend!

The game is sectioned into rounds. Each player takes turns, playing a single attack, movement, or spell card per turn. This continues until one player is out of action cards, and passes. If the other players have action cards, they can continue playing until all are out, which the final person to pass declares the round as ended.

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Sounds simple. methinks there is more to dis den dat!
You have no idea. There is a ton to manipulate and do and use to your advantage, from trapping floors and laying curses upon your foes, to Objectives within the field of battle. Adding to the mix are Traits and Handicaps, which can buff and debuff your team and your enemies to turn the tables in your favor!

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Okay. Carry on, I need some amusement while I harvest me crops.
At the beginning, you recruit three party members. You can choose from 3 races and 3 classes. This may seem a little lackluster, but this actually keeps things simple enough for the novice RPG player, and yet still adds a good amount of strategy to your party.

Dwarves are very tough, but are slow. Humans are decent in both movement and toughness, while Elves are very fast and have the bone structure of a sparrow.

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Wot of magic usage? Most of dese type of fings 'ave them differ in ability...
That's the cool thing. All 3 races are completly capable of rocking out as a mage due to how the magic and attacks are handled.

This leads me to the classes; The Warrior, the Paladin and the Mage. Sorry, thieves, the healer is more important, and Elf Warriors are pretty much the same.

The Warrior is able to wear heavy armor, can wield THREE weapons (Maybe the dwarves have prehensile beards?), and generally hit like a speeding truck.

The Paladin meshes Might and Magic nicely, heals and buffs their teammates, and can even lay down the smiting via curses!

The humble mage is a master of long-distance combat, but shines when you can hurl opponents with Telekenetics, block pathways with lava flows, and fling all sorts of elemental bolts, among many, MANY cooler things!

Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: How easy is it to pick up? me kin may try dis!
All that is needed is a basic reading ability, and elementary arithmatic for planning.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now let me get to the F2P aspects:

It is handled almost as good as Team Fortress 2 before the Robot Update. I ♥♥♥♥ you not

They introduce it throughout the campaign, but not only is almost all of it optional, but when they do? FREE IN-GAME CURRENCY IS DROPPED ON YOU AND YOU CAN JUST SKIP THAT ♥♥♥♥ OFTEN.

Rather get a free week of club membership? DO IT.
Like the standard look of your characters? PASS THE COSTUME SHOP.
Rather test your luck on a bunch of chests than go do the treasure dungeons? GAMBLE AWAY!

Even the Expansions can be attained from completing the Campaign (To my knowledge)!
I cannot stress this enough: These devs know how to do the Free to Play model right, and when I get the spare dosh, I am definitely rewarding these people not only for making this wonderful game, but also for treating the consumer so well that you WANT to spend money on their free game.

The only major hitch is that the voices can get annoying (Melvin, I swear to god if you keep being a douchenozzle I will give your hatchback a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hydrochloric acid bath), and that if you are not really interested in High Fantasy stuff, you are gonna be bored out of your skull.

If those don't bother you, Give it a try.

reviewText:
Card Hunter is a combination of a traditional collectable card game mixed with tabletop gameplay delivered to in such a wonderful presentation.

Presented in the form of a tabletop game board, each campaign is several levels or floors deep. Pitting you up against different foes with different sets of cards.

You are introduced to all the mechanics in a great way using the early missions as their conduit. You'll also unlock each of your starting party members one at a time over the course of the first hour or so of the game. Each of the character classes are: Warrior, Priest, Wizard and each of those can be one of these 3 races: Human, Elf, Dwarf. This gives you a chance to learn the basics with each one as you play. Tutorials tend to make or break strategy games, but Card Hunter does it in a simple and engaging way.

The single player campaigns are all a part of an overarching story where the brothers Gary and Melvin take a tongue in cheek approach of the dungeon master and player roles. This makes each encounter feel like a real tabletop RPG, especially with the art assets and introductions for each campaign.

Each of these campaigns is picked from an overworld map that looks like an actual paper map with little dungeons and shops that pop up as you progress. The attention to detail is one of the things I find the most fascinating about this game. Each character, game piece, card all look like real game pieces. Blue Manchu did a great job with the art direction on this and it shows.

The gameplay here is the star. Mechanically it's very deep, with 1000's of items that alter your deck. Instead of the traditional collectable card game trope of opening card packs and building a deck. You instead must equip each of you characters with one of those many items. Each item is a set of cards for your deck. So as you outfit your party with better weapons your card pool will get stronger as well. These items are obtained from completing the single player campaigns, playing multiplayer, or purchasing chests with a paid currency.

By making the deck building mechanic tie into the itemization of your party it makes you make decisions that normally you wouldn't do. As you progress, each character is given a certain number of major and minor power tokens, which gate the gear you can use. You will find some of the best loot requires some of these tokens when you're equipping your character. This prevents you from making a character to powerful. Much like traditional tcg's or ccg's would limit the number of copies of certain cards in a deck, this mechanic is essentially doing the same thing. Though what happens here is it forces you to make some tough decisions. For instance, do you equip the laser weapon with 6 awesome attacks or the divine item that gives you some extra heals. The way this customization works adds a nice layer of depth to the strategy of this game and one of the reason it has such replayability.

Besides the free content there is also 3 versions of paid content purchasable from inside the client. The Basic Edition for $19.99, the first expansion Attack of the Artifacts for $12.99 and the most recent expansion Expedition to the Sky Citadel, also $12.99. Each of these packs adds new campaigns, new items (which means new cards), new enemies, and new costumes.

In the newest expansion, Expedition to the Sky Citadel, your campaign is against the GM - Cardotron 2000. Adding content from levels 18-21 and also proving you with a level appropriate party in the event you are not level 18. This content is hard, at least the first of the six treasure hunts was. In my first attempt at it I lost several times. Hopefully I can get some more loot and try going at it again.

I know this is getting lengthy but there is also a well integrated multiplayer portion to Card Hunter. With ranked leaderboards, custom multiplayer maps and a separate load out for your party. You can play individual ranked games to prove your worth or join a ranked league where you play a set number of games in a certain period of time for rewards. The multiplayer seems balanced, although I haven't played enough of it to be 100% sure.

Overall, For a free to play game it can go one of two ways. Lot's of content locked behind paywalls, which make the game feel pay to win. Or a ton of content for free with paid options to progress faster. Luckily they went for the latter. It's always a plus when a free game goes that route, giving you plenty to do and then entices with new content to make you to want to support the game. Card Hunter brings a free, fun and unique card game/rpg to you and presents it in such a charming way.

https://youtu.be/JPJ8GNgCSjY

reviewText: Great idea for a card collecting game. Its sort of based on an old school RPG dungeon & dragons  board game with a geeky game host character. This is how RPG games were played before the arrival of PC games. The whole idea of a virtual board game complete with cardboard cut out characters and quest book stories actually works very well. reviewText:
Buffs
1. Lovingly crafted homage to non-digital RPG gaming (PnP, TCG, and board games).
2. Satirical story line involving noob GM, Gary and his hardcore older brother, Melvin is nostalgic and funny.
3. Tons of free content.
4. An editor allows you to create your own battles which can potentially be added to the game.

Debuffs
1. If even the positive reviews express frustration at the RNG then you know it's a problem. Forget about strategy and deck-building; getting a beneficial draw is so unlikely that I fail even in lucid dreams of the game (which after nearly 300 hours there are many).
2. Distribution of the card types attached to equipment is made with neither rhyme nor reason, causing unneccessary limitation and imbalance. Your warrior can choose 1 of 52 different martial attack items which buff everything from bash, chop, and penetrating attacks to bash, chop, and penetrating attacks. Do you like fire? Lucky you; you can load your wizard with 2 staves and 4 arcane items providing fire magic cards to be buffed by your pyrocentric arcane skill. Do you prefer electricity? You can go to hell; there are some nice shocking staves but not a single 1 of over 200 arcane items adds lightning attacks.
3. The game has been ensorcelled by dark magic to compel people to keep playing even as they rail against it. Even days after uninstalling I am plagued by images of bludgeon-resistant black oozes whenever I close my eyes.
voteText: 86 of 149 people (58%) found this review helpful 67 people found this review funny

reviewText:
More frustrating than fun.   Too much reliance on getting good results from random rolls/draws/loots.

Frustrating as hell to be in a difficult fight, and your warrior draws no attacking cards for 3 rounds in a row, while at the same time your healer doesn't draw any healing cards. And when you do finally draw that much needed attack card, your opponent blocks it with an armor or shield card.  It's worse than bad rolls  in a real DnD game. Here you have to randomly get the right card, then if the target has armor or a shield, you have to randomly succeed against his block.  In DnD you can always move and attack, and even if your attack rolls were bad, you weren't hamstrung by not having a card that allowed you to attack.

If you were unlucky not get good loot drops, it makes your life even worse.  Your cards available to you are dependant on the loot you get. Also loot that worked well in one adventure, may not work well in the next one.

The game won't let you sell usable items for quite a while into the game. Meaning you have tons of junk in your inventory that you'll never use and can't sell to buy stuff you really want.

The sterotypical dungeon master schtick with Gary and Melvin is amusing at first, but after a few adventures you start wishing they'd just shut up.   The whole cardstock aesthetic has it's own charm too.

Naturally being an online game you have to deal with full servers or servers being down.

It's worth trying for free, but I'd rather play a proper traditional RPG than this, personally.  It's kind of funny to me, that I feel like I would like this game better if I had never played actual pen and paper RPGs before.

reviewText:
Do you like Card Games? Have you ever spent hours upon hours playing D&D along with friends? Then stop reading here, Card Hunter is the game for you!

Card Hunter smartly mashes elements of both Collectible Card Games and Table-Top games, layering those with colorful characters and lots of humor, making fun of most common tropes about roleplaying. Finally, all of that is sprinkled with a myriad of references to gaming and pop-culture, resulting in a carefully crafted and absolutely charming experience.

The Single Player campaign is well put together and satisfying: the lower level adventures serve as a basic tutorial to the most important concepts of the game, easing the player into the ins and outs of an otherwise complex and deep game. As you keep going through the Campaign's story, the game slowly ups the challenge level, so the player is presented with a rewarding experience without feeling too overwhelmed. Wanna know what's best? You can tackle the whole Campaign cooperatively together with up to 2 of your friends and other fellow players, so you're not forced into playing the game on your own even if you don't like PvP.

Finally, if you like some good competition, you can jump right into Multiplayer mode and bring-it-on against other players. The MP mode features an automatic Match-Making System, so newer players are pitted against opponents of roughly the same skill level, making ranked matches much fairer.

There's a ton to be liked in Card Hunter and, while this certainly isn't a game for everybody, I'd seriously encourage all Steam users into at least giving it a try. The game's free to play, and the devs really do get the f2p model right. Not only can you play the game without ever spending a penny, if so you desire, but you're never faced with artificial pay-walls. Some game content (a few adventures and skins to customize your in-game characters' appearance) is accessible by paying-customers only, but free-players can otherwise access every item and card in the game via regular play alone, no microtransaction needed, minimizing the pay2win issues most similar games suffer from.

I'd also like to vouch for the indie developer making the game and the awesome community surrounding it. If you like your games to be frequently updated with bug-fixes and balance-changes, I assure you'll find all of that in Card Hunter. The devs also regularly work on new content to be added along with updates, with a big expansion usually being released once a year. If you try the game out and do like it, I strongly advise you visit the official site and join the forums there, as those are filled with great info and lots of people ready to help and very welcoming towards to new players.
voteText: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's already been 6 hours?

Card Hunter is an excellent tactical game in which you play a pen and paper game(Much simplified and game-y-fied of course) where you have a party of 3 heroes in a medieval/fantasy style setting. You go through questing modules and collecting loot to of course upgrade your own equipment and play through the storylines presented.

It's a charming game with simple but good graphics, a solid foundation for gameplay, and plenty of quests available. You do not seem to be hampered or stopped by paywalls, which seem to only be there to allow you access to more loot, cosmetics, and at times to unlock some new adventures. Not that you -need- those adventures, you can do just fine without them, but it does seem like it would be a good idea to get them at some point.
In game, you will find the movement and combat to be intuitive, with all moves being detailed on cards you play it is easy to look up what something does, and you won't find yourself blindsided by surprise gameplay changes. It's all about knowing your tools and using them well.
For the looting fans, you can spend your gold to buy extra loot chests, and for those who love to optimise everything there is a good variety of equipment available that is sure to get you exactly what you need to build your dream team.

While it starts a bit slow, it builds up quickly and gets in full swing fast enough to be comfortable without any moments where the difficulty hits you on the head.
I haven't even tried the multiplayer yet, but with the solid base this game has, co-op, and ranked play I seriously doubt I would be disappointed.
Edit: Checked out multiplayer, am not disappointed.
Another edit: Not all is fine with this game. Login queues are a thing, and it seems to be online only. This wouldn't be a problem if they had a 'cancel' or 'quit' button on the queue, but ctrl-alt-del is the only way out

As a summary, Card Hunter is a great tactics game with good atmosphere and as opposed to many 'free' games, this is actually a game you can play for free and enjoy. It is certainly worth giving a try
voteText: 15 of 21 people (71%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Cardhunter is the crazy love child of the 80s boardgame Heroquest and a simple card game.  The name is slightly misleading as there is no card collecting.  Cards are made available through many hundreds of items.  Deck building is done by equipping items to characters like any other D&D inspired game.  But unlike other D&D inspired games, the effectiveness of each item depends on how it synergises with other items.  An item with powerful cards will be balanced by also containing a number of weak cards.  All items are available for free and will drop randomly just by playing the game.

Many of the Steam reviews suggest this game is pay to win.  This is simple not true.  I became a top 10 player without spending a cent*.  I have seen some rich players dropping hundreds of dollars to fast track their item collection.  But you cannot buy any specific items.  So money gives them very little advantage.  Any seasoned player in the world chat will tell you the same.  You must grind your way to the top and this is a good thing.  The match making system makes use of Elo ranking, and will prevent you from playing against an experienced player that will definitely win.

Ignore the negative Steam reviews.  Instead go read the positive reviews on Kongregate - http://www.kongregate.com/games/bluemanchu/card-hunter/comments?sort=best

*After a thousand hours of gameplay I did purchase content, but only to support the developers.

reviewText: I really want to like this game. I do. But I've hit a point where all I can do is repeat a handful of vexing missions against what seems like ridiculous odds and can't seem to advance anymore. I am glad I only put a little bit of money into it because I think I'm done with it. As an example, I am a full level above one of the Treasure Hunt missions but cannot make any headway- the enemies have an endless deck of huge area effects that generate difficult terrain and they themselves have Hover. It gives a hint- to get robes that have Hover! Well, that's great, but I don't have any and at the time, there wasn't any in the stores that I could find, either. On top of that, it only means my squishy Mage gets Hover, since that effect only comes in robes, and then only if I happen to get that card at some point during the battle while the mage is still alive. I constantly find myself with Warriors that have lots of movement cards but no offense, or lots of offense but no movement. Another Treasure Hunt mission has my characters two full levels above the level requirement and is a capture-the-flag type mission with one victory space. Only the defending monsters are ridiculous, two of them have a seemingly endless supply of poison dart ranged weapons, the other two fly, have twice as many hit points as two of my three characters (and have one-and-a-half times that of my fighter), and a huge melee attack they always seem to have at the ready. If I am lucky with drawing movement cards, I can get within a few spaces of the victory square before my last character dies, or I take a slow approach, keep my characters alive, but lose on points. Twice I actually got a character on the victory space, right before death, and both times by the time I had gotten there, killing that character was the last victory point they needed to win. What else am I supposed to do? There are two missions a level below me I have beaten and two missions a level below me I can't beat (not to mention the level 7 treasure hunt two levels beneath me I also can't beat). Is this it? I really want to like this. I love the old-school-DnD art and tabletop RPG look but the puzzle-nature of the game coupled with needing just the right cards (that you may not even have access to) puts this soundly in the dislike" category. At least it is essentially free
date: though I did buy the Basic pack (and am regretting it now). I just can't recommend it."

reviewText:
Summary: Fun at first, I recommend palying it for a little while, but you will soon get bored. The prices are too steep, so don't buy anything, it won't be worth it. They missed too many simple things to warrant asking for purchases.

Its fun at first when you play with friends but the grind is real. The prices are a little too steep for me for the what you get. The game missed alot of simple things that would help, such as  tile labeling for communicating with friends. The blocking cards on the AI are pretty OP, they roll a block at least 60% of the time and usually have 3 or 4 of them while none of mine really ever blocked. You reach dead ends that you have to grind 5 or 6 times before you can progress, which is around the 7-10 lvls. I havent gotten past lvling my group to 11, because I get too bored. I recommend downloading it for a quick go to game, but once you get into it a ways in you will get bored. If you buy any of the in game transactions you really wasted money. I could've seen myself spending $5 back when I thought the game was fun, but $20? LOL. I'm glad I don't have buyers remorse. I want to get to the higher levels featured in the screenshot, but theres absolutely nothing that will keep me playing this game for that long. The grind is WAY to grueling.

A year later I remembered this game and picked it up again, they seem to have fixed the unfair rolling tables. I still find their prices extremely laughable. Plus for all the 'is it pay to win' confusion, it's a 'pay to not grind' so you get things much more quickly. All who find this not helpful are those that paid $100 and are salty about it lol

reviewText:
A cute little distraction while you wait for the next big dungeon-crawler to play.
If D&D and Magic the Gathering had a child, this would be it.

Free to play, with cash options to speed things up, Card Hunter never ceases to challenge, change up enemies so you have to change strategies, and tickle our fancy with culture-references. (I saw zoidburg, the acrobat from the old D&D cartoon, and much more!)

PROs:
-Fun, grid-based combat wil static D&D minis and flat terrain on a table. Adorable!
-Fast-paced, addictive, lovingly-crafted visual appeal.
-Correctly balanced for challenge, it never felt unfair.
-Enemy AI is more than competant (you CANNOT just charge in)
-Use of chokepoints, bridges and terrain is necessary to win, making you feel smarter


CONs:
-You are at the mercy of the dice and deck you build. It WILL screw you over more often than you feel it should. You WILL be helpless sometimes, eating multiple attacks and spells without any armor cards. You WILL pin bosses in corners and have nothing to hit them with sometimes. You WILL get stuck on acid, spikes, or lava from lack of movement cards. A LOT of this game is left to things out of your hands. Hope you've made your sacrifice to the RNG gods before you boot this game up.

reviewText:
Card Hunter is one of those games that look pretty boring and tedious, but once you start to actually play. You get into it and it becomes quite addicting.

Pros
-Not pay to win at all.
-Good flow
-Solid battle mechanics
-Multi-player
-Co-op (you can play along with friends)
-No constant grinding for items
-Easy to get rare-epic items
-Plenty of items

Cons
-In the beggining a pretty long queue
-Really short and really long battles
-Some exclusive items that aren't available without paying for for ex. costumes. (not really needed unless you wanna look snazzy)

But overall Card Hunter is a pretty awesome game, with few cons but i've only played for a couple hours so im sorry if i missed any other pros and cons.

reviewText:
*400  or so with the non-steam version.

Card Hunter is a Turn-based, Card Collecting, Tactical, Strategy Game. It does a lot and it does it very well.

One of my favorite games of all time I have spent countless hours on this hidden Gem. The artwork, the story, the playstyle. All executed very well!

Pros
+ Great Old School D&D Flavour
+ Is NOT pay to win at all
+ Likable characters in the Campaign
+ Fun competitive Leagues and online matches
+ Tons of Cards to collect
+ Opening Chest is super fun

Cons
- Lots of Grinding, lots (which to some people this is not a con!)
- No Trading (Which they explained why)

If you are a fan of Competitive Card Games, Board Games, Role-Playing games (although there isn't really any RPGing going on here). Give this game a try. With a beefy and fun Solo and co-op Campaign and an ongoing fun multiplayer environment with leagues, casual matches and custom made matches, there is a ton to do here. Best of all you don't have to drop a dime. (Although dropped a couple dimes here and there does support the development team)

reviewText:
A very interesting little game.

The idea is simple: move your characters around a battle field to fight monsters, complete quests and gain loot. The mechanic is what makes the difference. Each item you equip gives you a number of cards and you play these cards to move, attack, defend and cast spells.

There are a variety of quests and a multiplayer mode with both co op and pvp options

The game is simple to play but the tactics are actually very complex.

Although you can pay for additional quests etc you can have hours of fun for free and even playing pvp or co op, not spending cash does not put you at a disadvantage.

A fun game for casual or serious play

reviewText:
Fantastic game made better by co-oping with a friend. Card Hunter is a turn-based tactical board-game, played by creating a deck of cards you get by equipping items. It's intuitive and simple to learn, even for people unfamiliar with this type of strategy game. There's a campaign story that is simplistic but entertaining, and meshes well with the cartoonish graphics. It's sort of a D&D parody, but not in the sense that it mocks the genre so much as it embraces the sterotypes.

It is truly free-to-play, and though there are some paid aspects you can indulge in if you wish, there is no pay-to-win leaderboard aspect.

Oh, and this game does have dice rolls. Some days you'll get lucky. Some days you'll get milumbarred. It happens.

reviewText:
Been a long time Card Hunter fan and I'm glad it is finally coming to Steam! I probably have 1000+ hours in the game if you include the web version.

tl;dr: Neat CCG game that is free-to-play and *not* pay-to-win. Extremely fun and unique game with a cool retro feel, but can be overly random, imbalanced, and frustrating at times. If you enjoy CCGs and some light RPG stuff then check it out.

Obviously I'm a bit biased (both having played the game since beta and contributed published content), but I really enjoy the game and the unique things it brings to the Collectible Card Game (CCG) based format. Unlike many other CCGs, this game is absolutely NOT pay-to-win. In fact, some of the top rated players have never spent a dime. The content you purchase is really just for cosmetics, extra single player levels, or small boosts to collecting speeds (like 15% boost, which is not much at all). If you enjoy the game you should support it not so you get stuff, but so Blue Manchu can keep making new content.

The game is basically a mash up of a CCG with miniatures. You use cards to control the miniatures in an arena combat. Levels will often have interesting challenges that you need to overcome, with unique cards that can drastically change how you need to play. There's a decent amount of depth in when to play what card, when to pass early, and how to manage character facing and position. There's a lot to love, a lot to learn, and a lot to master.

While I do love the game, it isn't for everyone. It skins itself as an RPG, but it is much more a deck building / CCG style game. Some single player levels are extremely difficult and require you to rework your party just to overcome the challenges. Don't view it as an RPG where you get your stuff and slowly get better replacement gear -- almost every item has a use in some situation (even the super bad items are useful once you finish the game for Quests). This is both good and bad as it requires you to tailor your builds to the level, but also results in often playing a single player level just to immediately lose due to not having the right stuff" equipped.

Outside of that
date: my main complaints about the game is that it is a bit too luck based and imbalanced. There is the obvious card drawing element
recommended: but then there are dice rolls where a single one can make or break a match. Additionally
hoursPlayed: there are a few balance problems with some cards being overly dominant. If you're a hardcore CCG fan who wants to create an undefeatable build then the multiplayer game probably isn't for you. Yes
voteText: top ranked players are consistently top ranked (I was #1 for quite a while)
helpfulPercent: but that doesn't mean you won't lose matches against bad players just due to sheer dumb luck.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: the game is very unique and fun. Since it is free there isn't much cost in trying it out. If you enjoy CCGs and have a nostalgia for old school RPG tropes then this game is perfect. I'd recommend people check it out even if you're on the fence. At most you'll lose a few hours
votesTotal: but at best you'll find a new love like I did.\n\nIf you have any questions about the game feel free to contact me. Always willing to help out. =)"

reviewText:
So, if you like board games & tabletop, grid based tactics or card games, check out Card Hunter (now on Steam).

So far I have put a good chunk of time into it, and this game is a blast.

Why?


Pros:
------

1. Free to play.

2. Not true pay to win. You can unlock extra missions and treasure hunts with pizza, which is purchased with real cash. There is also gold used for items and chests (which can drop random gear, including the best). They give you enough pizza to unlock quite a bit of the end-game treasure hunts just by playing through the campaign, if you hold onto it. Gear drops from chests at the end of matches, and it's quite random with the loot drops (RNG). Everything can be obtained without a single spent penny.

3. Gameplay. Think your traditional grid-based tactics game... with cards. Instead of having set attacks, you draw cards each turn and that is what you have for that round. The cool part is that each character draws cards, and the cards in each characters deck are dependent on what gear you have equipped. Equipment in this game gives you various cards (which are your attacks and skills) instead of traditional stats

4. Campaign is a bit entertaining, sometimes repetitive, but good. Once you finish the game, you can redo any mission with special challenges that must be dealt with. These missions give you good loot drops.

5. Multiplayer: This game has 2 and 3 player co-op, as well as true 1v1 pvp. 2 player allows for an additional card draw per character to make up for the lack of numbers. It's an absolute blast. There is also true pvp multiplayer, which is ladder/elo based. In this mode, everyone is given 3 characters to use that are higher level (once you unlock them in the campaign), or your own characters once you finish leveling them. You get to use whatever equipment you have found as well. In my opinion, this is the true game. There are so many combinations between all of the gear, character race and class options that you rarely see 2 people of the exact same build.


Cons:
------

RNG. On occasion, it hits you with a left on card draws & defense rolls, and finishes with a big right to the jaw on loot drops.




- Boom$t!ck

reviewText: Fun, but the game won't allow you to do a co-op game using only one computer (I know that single player you can control all the heroes in your party but it's set up in a way that you couldn't play a multiplayer game with someone in that way). Also, inventory and equipment management is a hassle. There's a bunch of stuff that's labeled as useless and only able to be sold but there's also many different variations of them turning your inventory into a sack full of useless junk. I think it would have been way easier to just have given the player gold directly instead of having them waste time on figuring out whether something is equipment or junk. I digress. The game itself is entertaining so if you can get past the inventory and mulitplayer/co-op issues you should be alright.\n\nOh and microtransactions are shoved in your face... so that's annoying. reviewText:
I've played this game for ~2 years on and off. It's a game that strikes a good balance between card and board game. Needless to say I enjoy it.

It is also one of the few F2P games that I have thrown money at because I was enjoying it. Their F2P structure is quite fair. Most of it revolves around cosmetics which are really only for the cool factor. There is a subscription option that you can take for as much as 30+ days or as little as a week. Which really only gets you a piece of bonus loot at the end of a quest. Most of the times that bonus loot is OK but not mindblowing, so it isn't as if they are trying to bait loot you into subscribing. There are also Treasure Hunt maps that have a guarenteed one time drop when you first complete them. That one time drop will also show up as RNG loot throughout the game (quest level permitting) as well as cycling through the merchant shops for in game gold. I've also personally never been huge on most of the Treasure Hunt loot, I have personally fount it to be mostly OK but I seldom if ever use it. The Treasure Hunts for me are mostly for the fun of the quest.

tl;dr, the F2p aspects of this game are in no way pay to win and don't feel forced.

The PvP is even fairly fun, assuming you dont run into the flavor of the month team or have built a deck to counter said build. Ususally seems to be three dward wizards. I've found myself physically kringing when I load into a PvP match against them but there is something especially satisfying when you emerge victorious or better yet make them rage quit because your deck is set up to be viable vs other builds but almost completely shut them down.  PvP also has a pretty good reward chain. At least for the first 6 chests after which it really depends on if you are still having a good day or not.

reviewText:
From Blue Manchu comes the simple and fun free-to-play turn-based strategy game, Card Hunter. This Dungeons and Dragons-themed title melds customizable characters and roles with a combat systems that can be learned with very little play time. There are little-to-know pay-to-win features, utilizing the in-game currency (pizzas) for mostly cosmetic character items; pizzas can also be earned at certain points of the game, and players should not find it truly necessary to purchase theses pizzas unless they wish to support the developers in this admittedly fun title. This game can be quite humorous, and the dialogue and text can be quite interesting, so that is another plus.
Here are just a few reasons to Roll for Initiative in Card Hunter:

Gameplay - Card Hunter utilizes a grid in which to structure battles. Depending on which stage the characters find themselves in, hostile figures, obstacles, and backdrops will differ from previous encounters. There-in lies a question directed from new or potential players: what determines the actions player characters can make? Each character-individual forces when enemy non-player hostiles are involved- has their own deck of cards which define specific actions, maneuvers, and attacks that specific figure can perform. Once a player performs an action with a character, the enemy does so, and so on; these phases of actions continue until both sides pass their turns consecutively, in which both forces must discard cards until each individual figure has, at most, two cards each. This mechanic was likely implemented to entice players to commit to actions while not hoarding cards for later turns in a battle. The main objective, however, is to eliminate the opposing force by reducing each of their figure’s health to zero or below, or by other means described in scenarios within a campaign. There are also multiple races-humans, dwarves, and elves-in which players can add in any combination to their party, as well as varying classes that can be assigned to them.

Items - You may have heard mentions cards and asked yourself, “Why is this not a card game? Why is this portrayed mostly as a grid-based strategy game throughout this review?” To answer these questions, Card Hunter does feature cards that dictate actions and a maneuverable gird to which to strategize, but cards are obtained much differently than in traditional trading card games. In-game items are given to players after each battle as loot and there are varying slots in which they can be assigned; they also retained individual rarities and levels so that players can grade and compare cards that can be placed in similar slots on the player’s characters.

Character Leveling - As players complete adventure paths, their individual characters gain experience which boosts health points and possibly opens up item slots that allow characters to expand the card count and variability in their decks. For example, at level five my dwarven fighter now has the capacity to equip three weapons, as well as a martial skill and other helpful items which grant bonus cards and traits. Though leveling is a somewhat slow process, this is compensated by the abundance of quests that are granted to the player upon completing others; these quests also have a daily reset allowing players to complete them only once daily, but so many quests open up at once that this hardly presents an issue-after three hours of play I found no need to revisit on of my previously completed quests.
Theme - Card Hunter is a pretty blatant Dungeons and Dragons-themed title. The game’s Dungeon Master is named Gary after the legendary Gary Gygax, dice rolls are mentioned frequently in accordance to mechanics within the original roleplaying game, each adventure path’s synopsis and art is based on classic modules; it is fairly obvious yet awesome.


TL:DR - Card Hunter has a few features that could possibly mark it as a ‘fee-to-pay’ title, but after five hours of total play I have not utilized nor have I felt it necessary to utilize the paid functions of the game. This title is extremely fun, though I have not yet had the opportunity to experience either cooperative or player-versus-player online features; I cannot accept nor deny the credibility of the online community. Card Hunteris recommended for those who enjoy card- or grid-based strategy game. Also, if there are any new or existing players who would like to play cooperatively but do not know anyone else who plays, I would gladly join in. Thanks for reading.

Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

reviewText:
A mashup of collectible card games with D&D, plus a healthy dose of humorous nostalgia.  It's got an adorable art style, constantly shifting tactical combat, and a wonderful community.

It's also Free-to-Play, but not in a bad way.  You could play through almost the entire game without spending anything, but you can pay for a set of *even more* adventures (~20 more on top of the 50-odd free ones), get a slight boost in the number of items that drop, or go for excellent cosmetic upgrades.

It's the bestest!

reviewText:
Card hunter is a very interesting mixture of CCG gameplay with Tabletop RPG mechanics and an intentionally goofy plot that moves the player through its campaign. I started playing this game two years ago, going through the campaign on my own, having a blast customizing my deck to combat the various enemies the game throws at you while laughing at the tongue-in-cheek dialogue. After that, there was a whole other world to explore in competitive multiplayer with other players, with a system that matches the player up with opponents of a roughly equal skill level.

Now with the recent expansion, there's also the possibility to go through the campaign cooperatively with up to two friends, or team up to play a multiplayer match against another team. There's something new to keep you coming back to the game every day, such as special loot rewards for beating certain adventures or 10-hourly leagues which offer completely new scenarios to strategize in.

The variety of cards is absolutely huge, there's enough possible playstyles to accommodate anyone's tastes, and the constant collecting of new items and cards means you'll often find ways to adjust your characters to be even more to your liking.

Card Hunter is easily the best Free-to-Play game I've ever played with the richest and fullest experience without buying any in-game currency. It's basically as far from a pay-to-win model a Free-to-Play game can be.

Anyone, whether they have a casual or deep interest in the game, whether they prefer playing competitively, cooperatively or solo, whether they buy the in-game currency or not can enjoy this game!

reviewText:
if you go into it like I did, as a casual gamer, you will enjoy the game for multiple hours.  That being said, some of the campaign progression is slowed to have to grind for items to equip your characters with.  This is where a minor pay to progress aspect comes in, but again, it is minor.  This is because you can essentially grind past that either by switching over to multiplayer for a handful of games for better item drops, or repeat previous adventures for  gold to buy better items.  There are reports that at higher levels the game slows even more, but I'm only at level 7 currently after about 8 hours of game play. Item prices in the shops are a little steep and just reflects on a pay to progress (more quickly) model.  I wish there was a better tutorial for new players, but it only took me a few games to get the hang of it. The game provides a new element to card game play by providing the boardgame, so it is a nice mesh between card dueling and boardgaming.

The game has been losing players steadily and is currently only at 25% of its average players online at a given time compared to what it had when it released, only 6 months go, in July 2015. (per steamcharts).  Having that large of a drop over that short of a time should be an indication of the game's longevity.

I would give this game a thumbs up because there is a good number of hours were it will provide enjoyment.  That being said, there is a lot going against it as far as mechanics go.  The random number generator style of card play can be frustrating.  Selling items is a joke as there is no difference in gp value for a level 1 item, or a level 18 item.  Pay to progress models frustrated me because you either have to choose to grind for hours, or pay real money to get the items faster.  It also seems the developers are not interested in keeping players by ignoring any criticisms that have been made.  This game could have been great if the developers balanced game play, improved their mechanics, and didnt require players to grind for advancement.  There are plenty of ways to incentivise purchases but pay to progress, and pay to win for multiplayer, are the least player friendly ways to go about it.

reviewText: This has the potential to be a really great game. But if you do not want to spend money or grind old dungeons over and over for small rewards just to progress at later levels good luck. Higher level dungeons where you are at same item level as the dungeons or slightly below it all comes down to rng which kills the game. Whoever hits their armor rolls will win in battles making the game fustrating when you have to either grind to get over geared and over leveled to pass. Or spend money just so you do not have to keep praying to the RNG gods that the enemies always hit their armor roles and you never hit your armor roles. It truely kills a great game when it comes down to RNG later in the game if you are going the free to play route.

reviewText:
I like card games, board games, strategy games, and rpgs. This games has a mix of all my favourite genres. If you have similar likes then this game should appeal to you.

Its a free game and I like how the developers have made effort for it not to be a pay to win game. Play through the long campaign.  If you get stuck, visit the shop and buy some cheap common cards/gear and change your strategy. Certain cards work better than others on different maps. I played through the campaign without needing to grind. After that you will unlock quests which are more challenging. You can pay to unlock additional maps but it not necessary to experience the game.

Plenty of multiplayer options including ranked matches, co-op and league matches. If you are stuck ask someone to help you out. IF you have poor cards then play a league match with fixed deck. If you want to do well in multiplayer I recommend playing through the campaign first to become familiar with the game mechanics.

The more you play, the more you feel like getting some pizza.

reviewText:
Have you grown older and miss the old days of D&D? Are your weekly Pathfinder games not enough for you? Are you having trouble finding a party of adventures to dungeon crawl with you? Look no further cause Card Hunter brings challenging AI and tactical thinking that will keep you entertained for hours, and it's all free to boot.

create a party of three of your choice from from the following races and classes:
Races: Dwarve, Human, Elf
Classes: Warrior, Mage, Priest
Why not level each type that's a combo of 165 parties have at it!

Loot is well set up each class gets specific gear the only ones that are in common are the Shield (which both the warrior and priest get) and Boots (whichs everyone gets) not to mention each class and race get special skill slot. The awesome part is gear is how you get your cards. You don't pick and choose cards individually like a deck builder, but you find loot which have 3 cards attached them them; unless they are weapons which have six cards. The play style for each class is tremindous I can't say on play style is better then the other but there is deffinitely synergy to make a character awesome. Personally I'm thinking of making a life steal dwarven priest, a dwarven mage that plays keep away with a card that causes them to take damage whenever they move and a elven warrior that is hasty to get in close and deal some heavy damage. What type of class you play may fall to lady luck depending on the items your able to find.

I have yet to touch multiplayer I want to finish the single player first before I try it out, but single player and multiplayer is linked so that you use the same character and gear and levels are locked when you switch to multiplayer to create an even playing field.

Long story short if your a fan of table top RPG adventures this is the game for you.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a unique game to say the least, not because of the gameplay, but because of the idea. You are playing a tabletop role-playing game with a Game Master, and you control your minifigures and defeat enemy encounters by using skill cards. Anyway, lets just go on ahead to the pros and cons...

Pros-

The Concept itself is very cool, I being a Game Master myself. Thank you developers for making a game where the Game Master is actually somewhat relevant :-)

Graphically it is good, if you like these cheesy kinda graphics. It just makes it more unique in my opinion.

Lots of room for development. The developers will likely add a ton of content over time, which is really cool. Plus you can easily change whatever you want material wise. Want Legend Of Zelda themed pieces? Just change out some of the files and you have it!

Cons-

Combat, the combat itself is basic, and to similar to basically any other turn/card based games.

Costly, the extra content costs quite a bit, but I think the developers have earned it to some degree. Pay-To-Win elements when it comes to the multiplayer aspect of the game.

Conclusion-
Overall I find this game to be fun. There are some aspects of it that I believe could be changed, but this is a solid game as is and I recommend it. Bring your tabletop roleplaying to the PC using Card Hunter!

May your adventures be many and always end in reward!
-Donoknight, Founder of Tabletop RPG Gamers League

reviewText:
Card Hunter takes everything I like about turn-based RPG combat and makes it sing a glorious duet with the infinite combinatorial grace of a well designed collectible card game.  There is a MASSIVE amount of single player content for free, and the challenges (which reward rare loot for replaying each mission) completely alter the way you have to think, relative to your first time through.
The  multiplayer, which I swore I'd never touch at first - sucked me in for months. The fiction is best thought of as a cute gift wrapper for the game design, but honestly - it doesn't need more.

Finally, it just feels *patient*. You can feel like  you've made progress with only 20 minutes at a time, if you like, or binge for hours. A couple of years ago, as a new father with free time at weird hours, Card Hunter was a kind of refuge of clarity and safety-within-risk. But that was just MY reason to fall in love with it. Stop reading this. Find your own!

reviewText:
Remember back in the days where you used to meet up with friends to play tabletop RPG's?

This game got pretty close to that feeling, except what is missing is randomness in the story (there is 1 campaign AFAIK) and for me a 4 player co-op instead of a 3 player. Also the fact that the game rolls the dice for you.

When I first looked at it in the steam store, I didn't really think that this game (especially that it's free) would give me hours of great fun with friends. Boy was I wrong. After 8 hours of playing with friends and talking to them over teamspeak, we still haven't discovered 1/8 of the map! (it's huge!) There are lots of dungeons and items, ranging from wands or spears to lasers and mines!

There is a premium currency in the game called pizza slices" for which you can get various skins for your characters

reviewText:
Solid table top/TCG/RPG hybrid
8.5/10

My biggest grip is the title is a misnomer you don't hunt for cards, you grind against the rng for items that have cards attached to them permanently.

Pros
-Table-Top/TCG/RPG/Strategy/Turn-based all rolled into one neat little 190 MB package
-Addictive
-Lots of loot
-Challenging campaign with semi-funny npc convos
-Reading the text prior to battle gives you a sense of the dev's love for D&D (lots of references in npc convos)
-Good music and visuals for what it is
-Easy to learn
-Multiplayer with leaderboards and tourneys

Cons
-While not altogether not P2W since most items you will use can be found through battles.  There are some features that can be accessed solely through purchasing additional in-game currency, namely the treasure dungeons in the campaign (11 total) and some cosmetic features
-needs more cowbell

reviewText: It is an enjoyable game that explores the elements of the usual RPG and presents that in a style that anyone could enjoy. There are slow loading times but the gameplay makes up for it. However, the reason why I enjoy this card game over others is that it has character which makes me feel motivated as I build a stronger relationship with the characters I create and Marvin, who is a character I geniunely feel sorry for him as he is constantly being intimidated by his brother. With other games, you are given your cards, play a few games and then leave the game due to a dwindling interest. However, I feel like that this game would be interesting even without the stellar gameplay. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who has some time spare as it is a captivting game.

reviewText:
In a Nutshell
Card Hunter plays like a clever tactical board game with a good dose of geek humor that D&D players may especially appreciate. Best of all, it's free, and its microtransactions aren't necessary to win the game.

Gameplay
If Dungeons & Dragons were played as a board game with decks of cards to resolve combat, the result would be Card Hunter. The gear that your characters equip determine what cards go in their deck. At the start of each encounter, your party of characters and their enemies are deployed on the board, and each of them is given a hand of cards from their deck. The player and the Game Master alternate playing a card from their hands to move across the board, execute a melee attack, or cast spells. When both of them pass without playing any card, the turn ends. If there are any hands with more than two cards, these must be discarded down to two, and two new cards are drawn from their respective decks to form a new set of hands. Play continues until the player or the Game Master attains their victory condition.

There is no perma-death in this game, so even if your entire party gets killed, you can always start over with the same party if you want to.

My Evaluation
Using cards instead of dice to resolve actions is nothing short of brilliant. This game mechanic adds a level of planning that would not be possible with dice alone. If you enjoy turn-based tactical combat in a D&D-like setting, Card Hunter may be for you. This game doesn't come with an emotionally engaging story (not that you should expect one), but you may appreciate the geek humor that this game has in spades.

Note that Card Hunter has microtransactions, but they really aren't necessary to win. Over all, I find the developer's business model to be fair and well worth supporting.

reviewText:
Product received for free

This free game is surprisingly well-developed and fun for many hours.  I love the 1st ed. AD&D aesthetic (done tongue-in-cheek), combined with turn-based party RPG and card-game mechanics.  It's a fun throwback to old Dungeons & Dragons play, but lovingly mocked for its geekiness throughout, and updated for simple but deep tactical gameplay.

It's funny without sacrificing any of the actual nerd enjoyment of card-driven fantasy RPG battle tactics.  The perfect audience for this game is someone who loves these sorts of games yet also laughs at the dorks (always dorkier than ourselves, naturally) who played these games in the 1980s.

Beautiful graphics, extremely smooth lag-free play, clear user interface. In-game purchases available but totally non-invasive and inessential to success.  Worth $20, but the developers seem to be banking on the in-game purchases to make up for the excellent development.  No skimping here!

reviewText:
I have only been playing Card Hunter for a little over ten hours so far but this game is so good! It is super addicting but easy to pick up and put down as needed. It is also enjoyable to play on your own or with another friend or two. There are times where it is difficult to commit to campaigns and this really quells that craving to just build a character, step out into a fantasy world, and kick some serious butt.

The experience and loot gained is satisfying; sometimes you may get a piece of bacon for a resale value of two gold but sometimes it is a really awesome weapon with abilities that make your deck shine. There is a lot of strategy involved and this game provides a nice challenge. As a free player there are plenty of encounters to enjoy but I have to admit that I am looking forward to purchasing some adventure packs in the future.

The free model is excellent on it's own, but for those who like to invest a little and enhance their experience, it looks like Card Hunter has you covered there as well.

I am definitely getting my friends to play this.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Three characters, each with 4 cards to start.  You play until both players pass, either because they can't play anymore cards or want to draw more.   Then each character gets 2 more cards and another round begins.  Characters can move on board by playing movement cards.  Equipment determines the pools from which cards are drawn randomly.

OK for a free game.  Out of courtesy to developer, rating this up.

reviewText:
'Sunset. Or maybe dawn? Who knows..', Cuddlepie thought.
It felt like days ago when he and his friends last saw the sky. They had been crushing and slashing their way through zombies and skeletons for too long, way too long. Mr Jingles had already fallen... Wouldn't be long before fatigue got the best of him also.
'Damn our luck..', he mumbled. Their cart crashed probably at the worst place ever. He just knew that cottage was bad news. He could feel it, and his fears proved correct when the dead appeared and never stopped coming. They had hoped it would be just a few, easy to get rid of. But that was just wishful thinking.

Boppsy made a tough decision, but it was the right one. Perhaps someone else would have ignored the sinister laughs and the cries for help from the cottage and just run away. But not them. It was obvious that whatever evil lurked inside the cottage had to be dealt with, once and for all.
'By me beard, young lady, FOCUS!'. His thoughts were interrupted by Boppsy's fierce voice.
'I am trying, you silly dwarf! I already put that giant skeleton in the other cell, do you think teleporting others is as easy as swinging a hammer?' The wizard replied
'Perhaps you 'd like to do it then!', Boppsy laughed back, while breaking another skeleton in pieces. 'Cuddlepie, are you ready?'
'Always, brother', I replied.

We had finally reached the last chamber of the cottage and I was staring at the evil necromancer for some time now, only few meters ahead of me, yet so far away. The lava between us was impassable. I was exhausted but I was also ready to strike with my most powerful combo. Boppsy was right behind me, succesfully holding off the endless waves of the necromancer's minions at the narrow corridor between the two jail cells. The young, imprisoned wizard was in one of the cells, trying her best to help Boppsy and teleport me next to the necromancer for the fatal blow.
The necromancer was mocking us, throwing spells without caring if we die now or later...

'Finally!!!', I heard a faint yell. And time stopped
I tried my best to hold my senses. I had prepared my all out attack and now I also had the perfect block ready. My vision blurred and a split second later I was next to the evil necromancer. He didn't seem worried nor afraid I was next to him and he lifted his weapon to crush me down...
No, I wasn't expecting that. In my surprise I desperately threw my shield up while dashing on the right. It blocked his swing and he lost his balance, and he wasn't ready at all for my reckless swing that hacked him from shoulder to bottom.

The chaos had stopped.

RNG, as much as I f#!@&% hate you, Card Hunter has also taught me to love you.

reviewText: This game is not your average free-to-play. It is an extremely impressive game and will surprise you with just how good it is over and over. Unlike other games I play all day at work, I play this all night at home too. I happily forked out some cash to the devs. Tons and tons of quality time I've gotten playing this. And rarely am I inspired to write a review.

reviewText:
Card Hunter is a deeply enjoyable game. It's a fusion of traditional Dungeons & Dragons tabletop and Magic: the Gathering style card game presented in a charming aesthetic that mimics classic D&D boards. The mechanics, while odd at first are quick to learn and work very well. There's a full suite of some 30 multi-mission adventures on offer, along with fleshed-out PvP that's accessible basically right off the bat in a competitive state.

Oh, and all of this is free. Not bad, right?

BUT - and this is a very big BUT - the amount of RNG involved in the gameplay is absolutely through the roof. Each character you control draws every move (up to and including actual moving) from an unseen, randomly shuffled deck of cards. The only guaranteed draw is the basic movement card which is always given to you at the start of each round. Absolutely everything else from attacks to healing spells to self debuff cards is completely random.

It is maddening and sadly all too common for my fighter (big chap who hits things with a sword/club/lightsaber) to go several rounds in a row without drawing a single attack card, and then draw a single kind of crap one before going another round without. For a class that's supposed to be up close and personal at all times this is downright deadly, especially since in the campaign adventures monsters seem to have an incredibly strong chance of drawing their most potent attack more or less every turn. This also applies to the priest (healing and buff/debuff support) and mage (killing things from far away), who are also both often caught without anything useful in their hands in the heat of the action.

Don't get me wrong, Card Hunter *is* a good game. The positives definitely outweigh the negatives by a fair margin. But I cannot stress enough that it can sometimes be an incredibly frustrating experience because so much of it is left down to the whims of RNJesus. The only thing you have complete control over is the positioning of your characters. Play it, but be very aware of that fact because it WILL bite you in the ♥♥♥♥ with alarming frequency.

reviewText:

There are modules, pizza (store coin) and membership you can buy with real money.
