reviewText:
Disclaimer: I've received in-game premium currency for playtesting and creating custom maps.

Card Hunter is a free-to-play hybrid of collectible card game and turnbased strategy pretending to be a tapletop RPG. It has SP and MP modes, co-op, daily rewards, and a map editor. The big thing that makes it unique is the fact that you don't own individual cards; instead you're collecting items that contain 3 or 6 cards each. Each of your chars has their own deck created by the items they have equipped (36 cards once all equipment slots are unlocked) which they draw from during battles.

Combat involves moving your chars around on a 2D map (handmade, every SP map is unique) made up of several terrain types, but their actions are limited to the cards in their hands. Attacks can have ranges, area of effect, damage over time, buffs, debuffs, or even create special terrain types. Victory is based not just on what cards you have but also your skill in positioning and timing (the order you play your cards or pass).

It truly is free-to-play. Every card, item, race, and class is available for free. The only premium content are special character skins (purely decorative) and certain SP modules that give a specific item when you first complete them. But those items aren't the rarest or best in the game, and can be obtained from random drops and shops in both modes. The other main use of premium currency is Club Membership which gives an extra item every time you win a battle while a member. You can also use the premium currency to buy chests (booster packs) or convert to common curency for the shops, but those are considered to be wastes of money. There is no trading or direct purchasing of specific items you want, you have to wait for it to show up in a chest or shop.

Why do I love this game so much? Why have I played it every day for over two years?

1. Free. Singleplayer. Turnbased.
You just can't find many games that fit all three conditions.

2. Nice clear interface.
Ben Lee's artwork is beautifully clear and distinctive, making it easy to tell my chars apart. The boards are flat so my chars are never obscured by walls. Lots of useful information when you hover the mouse over things. Ability to mute the music and ambient sounds (they're not bad, I just don't like them in my games).

3. SP doesn't force you to play against humans.
It's a huge campaign of 73 modules (5 tutorial, 38 regular, 9 fan-made, 21 premium) most containing 3 battles and you can play every single one of them without ever facing a human opponent.

(If you'd rather play against humans, at about level 5 you'll be invited to MP and given a free premade party to get you started. Then you'll have to play one more game against the AI to introduce MP rules (timers, draw limits) but after that you can disable AI opponents and play only humans from then on.)

reviewText:
Fantastic  Free-to-play  game that I thouroughly enjoyed playing with friends. The story is witty, interesting and very enjoyable. This game is simple yet complex and involves a lot of in depth thinking to win a game against other players. Overall, this game is a proper Free-to-play and involves absolutely NO pay-to-win ingame transactions. You however, can use the ingame currency (pizzas) to buy skins and extra loot chests. Every item in game, every player can get. There are also extra adventures that you purchase if the campaign isn't long enough for you.

reviewText:
This game is pretty awesome.
I played the flash-version before, but since it is now on steam and has coop, i began a new game and am now playing it together with 2 friends in coop. And i have to say this game is even more fun in coop.

You really have to plan the moves together and build your party accordingly to the enemies to defeat some of the harder levels. I also love that there is such a variety of factors deciding the match. Just equipping the strongest items wont get you far. Since it is a deckbuilding game there obviously is a element of chance in the fights, but i you can compensate that pretty good by choosing the right equipments.

As for the buisness model, i have to say this is an extremely fair free to play title. You can play this game completely without paying a dime. Paying will just give you a little more loot, different looks for your heroes and access to bonus levels. So you should consider buying this as a thank you to the developers, for letting you play such a great game.

reviewText:
A surprisingly fun little adventure game where you can either play solo with a party of your own characters, engage other players in multi-player colluseum-style matches, or group up with two other players and tackle challenges together. Progression of characters focuses on loot (which gives you different actions) and health, but the game mantains a consistent level of challenge regardless of what echelons you've climbed.

In terms of pay-to-play content, it exists, but seems to consist mostly of special adventures (with special loot no doubt) and different models for your characters, but nothing must-have in order to enjoy the general premise of the game.

Definitely more fun than I thought it was going to be, and something I have no doubt I'll senselessly pour lot's of time into.

reviewText: Being an oldskool (tapletop) RPG'er and avid MMO-RPG fan, this game is so great to fall into :) It takes me right back to countless days/evenings/nights spent with a group of friends sitting around the table playing D&D... In any case, this game is completely free-to-play, total eyecandy and a ton of fun. (I revisit it every once in a while and keep enjoying it for a few games now and then.)\n\nRecommended !

reviewText:
Card Hunter has some interesting mechanics worth exploring, all wrapped up in a well-exectued, if well-worn, theme. This is the first game I played blending a card game with a tactical RPG and it does so very well, with your character's deck being based on their gear - which makes it very easy for the RPG fans out there to ease in to the deck-building. Being an RPG fan myself, I can't say that this system does much for the deck-building fans out there, however.

Over all, it's a fun romp and worth a couple hours of your time, if just to check out the systems in play. After all, it's free!

There are a few microtransactions offered, but none are necessary to progress fully through the game. I can't speak to PVP or Co-Op, as I've only played the Campaign.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I have often tried to find a decent PC version of old Pen And Paper games.  I loved playing RPGs as a kid-my older brother would make campaigns for me and my other brother to play, and while I have nobody to play with where I live now the desire to relive the fun is strong.  Card Hunter is the closest game I have found so far to capturing the paper RPG style I am looking for, even with the card game features.  It is fun, and once you start playing it keeps you wanting to play even when you know you should be doing something else.  Best of all, it is free!  I would recomend this to other people looking for an old school RPG experience, especially if you don't have the dosh to by a more complicated game.

reviewText:
There are plenty of reasons to play this game, but I cannot recommend it due to the game itself.

It's easy to end up with no way to move out of an enemy that is stacked full of attacks that will kill you, but because you don't have any movement cards you're screwed.
Due to this it's almost definitly a good thing to play as Elves because of their long movement range, but I do have a feeling that the game encourages you to play different races with different abilities.

Due to the games cards it's very random if you succeed or fail a hard level, sometimes you can get wiped one play and utterly massacre the next due to RNG, so if you like that, Great! If you hate it? Well we will probably agree, it's not a fun game because of it.

Then there is the proof of Free to pay" game it is where it offers you special games and extra loot if you pay for a premium currency
date: however it's based in IRL time and it doesn't matter if you sunk 500 dollars on it earlier
recommended: if you just ran out you will be left without anything in the future. Unless you pay more."

reviewText: An incredibly well balanced game for old and new players.\n\nI've been playing Card Hunter since last year and it continues to impress. Excellent pay model that rewards playing rather than paying (Payment is more geared towards expansions and cosmetics rather than advantages). The deck building is simple but indepth and the community is always on hand to help. Multiplayer is where this game shines. You recieve rewards every time you win and they have multiple leagues daily that contain different maps/creatures/rules on a rotation basis so when you have mastered one a new one pops up. Leagues contain rewards for each participent and increase as you climb the ladder so new loot is always being obtained.

reviewText:
I've played this game for hundreds of hours over a couple of years prior to its release on Steam.

Briefly, it's a fun, charming, challenging turn-based collectible card game with a neat tabletop theme. You move your characters around a dungeon game-board, and attack enemies, using cards drawn from the deck of cards each of your characters has. The most unique twist Card Hunter has on this genre is that your decks aren't built simply by placing whichever cards you want into your decks, but by equipping your characters with items, each of which brings several cards to the table. This means you have to weigh the advantages of the stronger cards on items against the disadvantages of their weaker cards.  It starts simple but very quickly will require you to tailor your decks to face specific challenges - such as trying to maximise the number of longer range attacks you bring when facing enemies that like to dance out of range of short range melee attacks.

The free to play model has often been called *too* fair; you can get a remarkable amount of game without ever spending a cent. It isn't pay-to-win, and there's no difficulty-paywall to make you feel that you can't progress without paying; tailoring your decks and strategies will see you through all the challenges that seem too hard at first, rather than forking out for subscriber advantages. To be frank, most people who end up subscribing do so as much because the developers have earned it as much as to access subscriber priveleges.

There are several multiplayer modes, and the primary one is deep, complex, challenging and immensely satisfying. I've played a hell of a lot of Hearthstone and Scrolls, and my wins in Card Hunter are far more exciting and satisfying than in either of those games. Other multiplayer modes (primarily Leagues) vary from more casual and random to differently challenging games using the same core systems, and they're a lot of fun too. The community is, by the standards of such games, excellent. You'll rarely have trouble getting help and tips, and it's very rare that people don't win or lose with good grace.

All in all, if you like strategic turn-based games, and/or CCGs, and/or tabletop games, or if you're just curious about any of these things, you owe it to yourself to try Card Hunter out. I think it's probably the best free game I've ever played.

Oh, a sidenote about the latest expansion which launched simultaneously with the game's release on Steam: I already loved this game a lot, but hell, these are the best, funniest, coolest campaign maps in the game! The nods to System Shock 2 seem cool until you realise that some of the devs *worked* on SS2, then the nods become mindblowing. I couldn't stop grinning the whole way through!

The Steam client seems to be fine.

reviewText:
Buy this game! ...oh wait, it's free... Try this game!
Then buy the developers pizza! They deserve it.

Free to play, all classes, items and gameplay modes (singleplayer and multiplayer) are free.
Pizza (cash) buys cosmetic items (character tokens), increases the speed of progress (extra loot per victory) and unlocks additional scenarios (so more loot/xp/fun per day).  None of which is required to win.

reviewText: I hadn't heard about this game before it got to Steam. I think what surprised me most about it was just how polished it feels. The UI is very smooth, the combat log clears up any confusions about what happens, and the occasional nerdy banter and tabletop feel adds a lot of humor to the game. The gameplay itself is also fun, it definitely doesn't feel like a ripoff of MTG or other card games.

reviewText:
Downloaded the game at 8pm and promised myself that I wouldn't spend anything on it, and that I wouldn't spend too much time playing it either.

3:45am and $25 later, I realise that despite being hungry and thirsty for several hours, I hadn't changed my body position at all since purchasing the game at 8pm.

**Warning - May lose any concept of day/time whilst playing and you WILL also deprive yourself of basic human needs**

Will be approaching my girlfriend today and explaining to her that for the next few months.....I'm as good as dead.......and will then be placing an obituary in my local newspaper declaring my death, so that nobody attempts to contact me and distract me from this masterpiece of a game.

10/10

reviewText:
Ok. Now this is fun. If you like tabletop dungeon crawlers, P&P rpgs and/or collectible card games you'll like this mix of the three. The mechanics are well thought out and the game is nicely presented.

So far I have only tried single player, need to tell my friends about this to get some co-op testing going. But as far as the SP goes this game is completely free. There are ways to make things a little more convenient using money, but there is no need to use them. The single player campaign is quite enjoyable without spending money.

So far I fully recommend testing the game for yourself, since it's for free.

reviewText:
Ok. Now this is fun. If you like tabletop dungeon crawlers, P&P rpgs and/or collectible card games you'll like this mix of the three. The mechanics are well thought out and the game is nicely presented.

So far I have only tried single player, need to tell my friends about this to get some co-op testing going. But as far as the SP goes this game is completely free. There are ways to make things a little more convenient using money, but there is no need to use them. The single player campaign is quite enjoyable without spending money.

So far I fully recommend testing the game for yourself, since it's for free.

reviewText:
There's really three aspects to this game - campaign, special campaign levels, and multiplayer.

Campaign is entertaining for a few hours, before it becomes obvious how it's the same over and over. Then it's and endlessly repetitive grind. Also somewhat too easy on every level.

Special campaign levels (Mauve Manticore) really goes the opposite way as the mother of all RNGs. You are forced into 30-50+ retries just because it was literally impossible with the cards you were given. Like you have 4 turns to kill an enemy and you are given no weapon cards, just block and move.

As the special campaign levels are visible on the campaign map like every other level, I really want to complete them - but it's seriously idiotic how they are 98% RNG-dependent.

Buying all the DLC is $45.

Multiplayer I haven't tried.
voteText: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I started off liking this game, but as a fan of strategy games over time increasingly I found less to like about playing it. As you advance the game pits you against increasingly stacked odds. The problem is your cards are all drawn random, so if you do not get just the right draw combination on many maps there is no recovery and you have to start over. Not that random cards are totally bad, it is just that your opponent does not seem to follow the same rule. Your cards are random but the computer seems to have attack cards, move cards and defense every turn. Random cards for the PC would have balanced play but it does not appear to be designed that way.

Some may like this style but to me anyway this totally negates strategy in the game, it comes down to random card draws and luck. If you find frustration and yelling at the computer when you need an attack card and get all move cards, die and have to start over, this is the game for you. Me personally it is being uninstalled.

Nice idea to mirror an old table top game, but poor implementation.

reviewText: I've played this for two years already via Blu Manchu's site. This is the only multiplayer game to date I've ever sank money into, mainly because I want to reward the devs for their hard work maintaining such a good game. There's a great community and the devs are friendly and approachable, and incorporate user feedback/content into the game. Get into it, it's great.

reviewText: Card Hunter started out as a browser game and got me hooked before it's release on Steam.  It is a fusion of D&D and deckbuilding.  Every piece of loot you collect adds specific cards to each of your party members' decks.  You draw cards each turn and try to make the most out of your spells, melee attacks, heals, and movements.  Dice rolls are made with many of the blocking cards so there is an element of chance.  Other than that, the rest of battle is affected by how you build your decks.  This game is free so it's definately worth a try.  You can pay actual money to gain access to more loot, campaigns, and cosmetics.  If you like turn-based combat and/or deckbuilding, you'll love Card Hunter.

reviewText: game is good for a few minutes, until you realize that it is just a money grab. as you progress LITERALY half of the levels are unplayable (locked) unless you pay REAL money to unlock them. the few levels that are unlocked get brutal so that they force u to play levels that you have already beaten OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER until you hopefully FINALLY get a level and can try to beat the game breaking levels pit you against enemies that can hit you from clear accross the map, and kill you before you can even make it near them. on top of that, the entire looting system is a grab at your money.. as they show you the loot that you COULD have on a pillow.. then, when u pay the money for a 7 day loot expansion or whatever, the quality of the loot goes down, in an attempt to get you to pay even more money for further rewards. i am so tired of people taking a half-♥♥♥♥♥, decent idea.. then just ruining it with greed and lies. this game is in no way FREE TO PLAY. if anything, this game is 'free to attempt to play.' meaning that the game will force you into monotany if you dont give it cash. if you dont pay cash the level curves will force you to spend DAYS literally DAYS playing the same lower levels for SEVERELY reduced rewards. i have lost all faith in steam at this point.. every other game on steam is a pay to win game anymore.. riddled with bugs, released way before its finished, and constantly pushing for you to spend real money in game... it doesnt make any sense.. how has gaming become this? i used to be proud to be a nerd, and proud to be a gamer.. playing real games, like Azure Dreams, Final Fantasy Tactic, Star Ocean, etc.. now it is a sickening grab for cash, a disgusting expoitation of our love for gaming.. this isnt even a game, like most steam games, it appears to be a game, however, it is really just a machine that is designed to lure you in with lies, gain your interest, then exploit you for money if you want to experience the game properly.. im sickened.. truly sickened by this game.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game now for almost 2 years.  It's a great mix of turn based tactical game and collectable card game.  It is a F2P title but the developers are very good at developing a model that avoids the pay-to-win syndrome.  You can spent money to get random loots faster, buy certain premium quest modules, and cosmetic figure outfits.

From my prospective, one of the best part about this game is the fact that each game could be done in 10-20 minutes or less and there's no problem with taking a break.  So it's a really good game for people who are busy and can't spent more than 30 - 40 minutes at a time.

All in all, this game has kept me entertained for a long time now, and I look forward to additional contents from the developer to keep this game growing.

reviewText:
Well, this game is a bit of fun, but falls short of its potential.

First, the nerdy GM should say everything that he's saying in written form instead of just instant comments.

Second, there should be choices between encounters that would affect the battle in question (allies, dependants, wounded monsters or heroes, (de)buffed heroes or monsters, etc.) according to the choices made. Otherwise why call this a role-playing game since there is no roleplaying? Gaining levels is not a roleplaying game that's a level-up game.

Third, combat is simple, somewhat fun and does not take forever to go through one fight. I don't like the card system for armour, it's dumb, you are either wearing your armour or not, it should not depend on your cards, it's silly. Skills on the other hand should, even though I find that silly too but it's a card game. Permanent items like armour and shields should always be in effect and not count as a card. There are some challenging fights out there too.

Fourth, microtransactions, yay! I'd rather buy the game that being faced with begging Devs, because that's how I see game devs that puts micro trans in their game, beggars. You can go far in the game without using any mt.

Fifth, having an adventure where you explore an area would be great. It wouldn't be just hack'n'slash turn-based.

I recommend barely this game, I think the dev / pub should sell this game and remove all micro trans from it. The mts are really not worth any real money. I won't waste money to make one, and only one of my character look different. Why the hell would I want to pay for that?

If you don't like micro-transactions, stay away from this game. But since it's free for a good way, try it out if you like Hack'n'slash tactical games.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very fun aspects of the game. However there are two major issues that really limit it. First off the leveling system they have in place doesn't let you replay any previous dungeons if they are a couple levels below you. If you try your level will be drastically reduced, you won't get any experience whatsoever, and because of your artificially reduced level you will also now be too low level to use your own gear! So apparently you are expected to constantly lug around tons of worthless low level gear for your party just in case you want to play any scenario deemed below you (which is generally like 90 percent of them) and you will also get nothing whatsoever out of it. FUN!

Second it's very micro transaction heavy. There are a very large number of skins, and now scenarios (including the new Penny Arcade ones) that you simply CANNOT play unless you pay. This is not an issue of paying to advance more quickly, this is literally walling off part of the game forever unless you pay up.

I'd much rather just pay once for a full priced game than this nickel and dime b.s.

Avoid until/if they ever figure out a better pay structure

reviewText: Solid game that is, in my opinion, hurt by a reliance on luck.\n\nI may come back and do an expanded review later, but for now I'll keep this short. The game on its face is fun, but the combat relies HEAVILY on random dice rolls. A string of bad rolls WILL mean that you fail a mission, no matter how skilled you are or how well you've built your characters. Add to that the enemies seeming to get very powerful cards just a little ways into the game (rank 7 missions, and even earlier) and it can get immensely frustrating incredibly quickly. It may be that enemies have smaller decks than the player characters do, which means key cards (armor, powerful attacks, etc) come up more than they do for the player, or it may just be my poor luck, but at the end of the day, when no amount of strategy can win in the face of a string of bad luck, I can't recommend this game. In my opinion, a certain degree of luck in games is fine, but when the ability to even make an attack comes down to luck of the draw, I think that hurts the game. It's not a bad game by any means when the other components are taken into consideration (art is good, the tone of the game is humorous, and the mechanics for character progression and deck building are fun) but it is very frustrating when battles are won or lost based almost purely on RNGs.

reviewText:
TL;DR I would not recommend CardHunter. The game mechanics are interesting and fun but it is pay-to-not having to grind and you are playing an RPG without story or immersion or atmosphere.

It is such a shame that a really great idea for mechanics is wasted because of greediness (asking money for content and loot) and laziness (no story, animations, atmosphere).

PROs:
- Game mechanics are unique and interesting. It is basically a puzzle game (which gear to equip for which battle) meet tactical combat a la XCOM.
- The whole meta" aspect - you play someone who is playing a game - is funny (for about 15 minutes).

CONs:
- The devs ask you every 5 seconds for real money. Big portions of the game are only available when paying for it. Image that in The Witcher you are being asked to pay 4 Euros to enter this dungeoun. The game really is all about loot (cards). Every single action a character can perform - even to walk - comes from cards which come from equipment. Loot is everything
recommended: you can grind your way to victory over countless hours or simply pay cash to get loot. At the same time
hoursPlayed: the  price per month is about the same as for a triple A MMORPG

reviewText:
Pay to win

The campaign is fun to play through the first time.

The multiplayer is not fun. The futuristic direction made previous cards useless. The RWG on loot and during play gets old. The random generation generally doesn't give you enough rare cards in relation to how many times you have to win against players who simply bought their decks. There is rampant cheating and people taking advantage of leaderboard mechanics. Cheaters can see your cards and magically have a counter. People take advantage of the leaderboards by intentionally trashing their own rank in order to get consecutive wins".

The mechanics of how cards work is also confusing. Combinations are difficult to create unless you spend the time to understand the mechanics of a card rather than what it actually says.

It was fun for a while but

reviewText:
Card Hunter did make a decent first impression with the interesting table-top theme and selected mechanics.  Other reviewers have covered those well enough.

I gave it a fair shake with over a dozen hours of play this week so I'm here to tell you that playing this game beyond the first impression is awful.  The table-top theme becomes very burdensome, limiting the maps to roughly 1/3-1/2 of a 16:9 monitor.  The fancy dice or whatever that you see in the screenshots are useless borders.

The DM" is a series of running jokes about pizza

reviewText:
After playing this game a fair amount, I cannot recommend it...ever.

Pros:

- Great board look and design
- Nostalgic ride to those days where there were no consoles or computers.
- Simple to learn
- Capacity to revisit maps for different loot
- A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of loot variety
- But that's it...

Cons (here, the crap hits the fan really):

- No tactics or strategy at all...just plain luck to win...IF you win.
- Only 3 classes to play
- You always draw cards that you don't need.
- Much of the loot is useless
- Pay to win at 100%
- AI blocks EVERYTHING...you block nothing...
- Grindfest
- Repetitive
- You are ALWAYS overwhelmed since AI has loads of npcs and you can nver have ore than 3 chars
- Cards have random crap that has nothing to do with the class
- The game makes you grind endlessly until you are actually capable of killing the next level npcs.
- Difficulty is ridiculously high
- I stress again the LUCK factor: no point in planning decks or strategies.
- Low epic drop rate...mostly you will get garbage after a huge effort to finish a level.
- It's like going to a Casino.

- Avoid at all costs. If you want a board game type...this ain't it.

reviewText:
This game requires its own set of login credentials on top of those required by Steam, defeating the point of Steam as both DRM and user authentication.

The accounts cannot be altered or deleted, and because made a mistake when creating mine, I can't play, and the developers aren't interested in changing this behavior. The only redress is a long process in which I have to justify my reasons for asking for a new account (I haven't even played yet) in writing.

This practice clearly wasn't considered. As a computer user I have dozens of authentication sets that I have to track without adding every single game I play. Every publisher that adds an additional login layer thinks that they are special - that I should make this exception for them. They give reasons that they think are sufficient to justify the policy. They're wrong. I wouldn't track extra logins for the other 190+ games that I own; why would I track yours?

reviewText: The game is fun up until about level 5 level 6ish where you can't play any further due to lack of proper cards and gear. This is where the 'f2p' ends and you have to start fishing out real money to buy 'pizza' to buy gear or subscribe so you get the bonus gear in dungeons which is even MORE money. OR you can go back and grind a few dungeons, BUT this requires anything that you used a power core on to be removed because you no longer have that. So you lose equipment in order to redo earlier dungeons which makes them pretty much as difficult as they were the first time around FOR LESS EXP AND GEAR than the first time you ran it. So it is all pointless if you don't plan on spending money. On top of the fact that you can't really redo a dungeon unless you wait a day for it to cooldown in order to get as much as you can out of it. Its a good timekiller for about 30 minutes and then it requires cash. Would not play again, deleting it from my steam.

reviewText:
Alright, as you can see I've put 90 hours or more into this game in just two weeks. Admittedly, some of that was me leaving the game on. But I digress.

As others have said, this game starts off as fun, but challenging. Around the level 6-7 area is where the game actually begins to get more fun and challenging at the same time. it is a very fun and satisfying experience when you overcome a very stacked battle against your adventurers, but soon the tedium sets in and you start to see the unfair difficulty in spades. Soon you realize just how stacked odds are against you when you actually play and count the number of random dice rolls and the like in a fight and how the game *Perhaps* manipulates the battles and cards as you play.

Example : You and your party are up against armor shredding enemies who have 2 space attack cards that go through armor and 1 space attack cards that discard all your armor cards. These enemies only pull 13-16 cards at the beginning of the match and they are for the most part 90% good cards. Enemies have Failure" cards such as discarding all blocks
recommended: which can mean you'll have an easier time for that round and perhaps the next. The problem is

reviewText:
Meh.   Interesting game play.  The graphics are about what you'd expect for a java based game, but if you're playing this game you probably are much more interested in the atmosphere and game play.

Each dungeon is basically a set of room battles, and cards are dealt to both sides that they can use during the fight to move, heal, hack... etc.  The biggest issue for me was that after each room battle was completed, your health and card deck was completely reset, so worrying about future battles at all doesn't play into the current battle.

Progression of your characters is somewhat stiffled if you don't purchase an extra loot slot" that gives you an extra toy after you win a fight

reviewText: As thematic and boring as THAC0Card Hunter's premise is that you are playing a pen-and-paper role playing game that is run by Gary, a novice game master, who is bullied by his neckbeard brother, and has a crush on the hot pizza delivery girl. These brief interludes before every campaign mission are easily the best part of the game. They do a great job of capturing the humor and nostalgia of every nerd's high school pen-and-paper role playing sessions. Sadly, these story sections don't really mesh with the gameplay. Gary introduces the missions, but there's never any dialog during the combat. It feels like someone wrote the story and then the combat system was farmed out to a different team. The gameplay just isn't as fun as the story.\n\nThe first big problem is all those Cards you're Hunting. Each item that you equip adds its entire set of 3 or 6 ability cards to your character's deck. If you understand basic UI design (unlike the Card Hunter devs), you'd probably expect the game to have a character screen that clearly shows which cards each piece of equipment is adding to your deck. Maybe with a column of equipment slots, with each item's cards shown to the side. But they didn't do that. So maybe your second guess would be that all the cards in your deck are at least organized sensibly, so that if your mage's deck contains two Firestorm cards from his staff, and a third Firestorm from a magic ring, the devs would at least program the game to give you the OPTION of clearly showing those three Firestorm cards all together, presumably beside any other fire spells that are in your deck, right? WRONG AGAIN! This cool cards-from-equipment idea was handled in the WORST way possible - each item's cards are just squished against each other in the deck, without any sorting or clear visual boundary between the sets of cards. And to make things even worse, some missions will force you to change much of your equipment (for example, you'll need lots of attacks that hit multiple enemies for a mission that swarms you with goblins) but there's no way to easily switch between decks" (equipment loadouts)
date: so you're stuck wrestling with the terrible interface much more than you should have to.\n\nOh
recommended: and when you're browsing a shop (there are several
hoursPlayed: presumably just to make shopping more frustrating
voteText: since there's no danger or cost involved in moving between stores) whenever you mouseover an item so that you can actually see what its cards are there's a cute little unrolling scroll animation before you get to see what its cards are. And no
helpfulPercent: it can't be disabled. You have to endure it every... single... TIME when you're just trying to slog through your mess of equipment. (Did I mention that I've put several hours into the game but still haven't earned the right to sell crappy equipment? I know you get to sell junk eventually
votesHelpful: but it takes way too long to show up.)\n\nCards have some basic numbers to show how much damage they do and their maximum range (although these don't increase to reflect passive buffs)
votesTotal: but anything more complicated than that requires you to zoom in on the card to read a mess of confusing keywords that should have been replaced with icons. (The keywords are such a mess that some "piercing" type weapons do "penetrating" damage that ignores armor. Really?! You had to use two different terms that have the same meaning everywhere but in your game? You couldn't call them "thrusting" or "stabbing" weapons?)\n\nNext problem - movement! I like games where the position of your units is important
votesFunny: but movement is very cumbersome here. You can't move unless you have a card that specifically lets you
commentsCount: and you can't "save" some of its movement for later in the turn. Combined with the fact that you only get to play one card before the enemy gets a turn

column17: making your hand full of attack cards useless. Each adventurer does always get a basic movement card in addition to whatever cards he randomly draws from his deck
column18: so you're not completely reliant on getting lucky and drawing a movement card
column19: but it just isn't enough.\n\nIt's crucial to know how much health each character has left

column21: but their appearance doesn't change to show how bashed up they are). You can see your adventurers' health numbers at the bottom of the screen
column22: but it's not shown as a health bar or anything else eye-catching like that. Just numbers.\n\nHere's a bonus tip for slogging through this review of all the game's problems: Gary will give you pizza (premium currency) so you can get a free taste of stuff that normally costs real money (such as hero skins) but the game lets you spend the pizza on actual useful stuff like club membership for bonus loot."

reviewText: Game is fun but unfortunately it's Free to Play. Sure it's not pay to win, you have to pay for cosmetic skins and DLC dungeons, but problem is in server calculations. To prevent cheating and hacking all game actions (every smallest action even in singleplayer mode) is calculated via online connection to server. And right now it means several minutes of queue waiting just to launch game and several seconds of lag after every single action. So I recommend to wait. Either online population will go down or devs will increase server capacities.

reviewText:
I reccomend this game as another timewaster and something of a decent quality. I do not however reccomend it as a game with any connection to what it satirizes. The gameplay is nice, the art is pretty decent, the humour is kinda bearable, but do not expect anything more than a grind and some story.

They could have done much more, but they chose not to. There is no choice involved at all, no character customization beyond choosing 1 of the peices they sell and equipping gear with no visual component. The DM characters constantly remind you with bad jokes that your not playing anything resembling the games initial appearance. Its all fighting, getting gear and leveling up.

If you want a game where you play levels, something like angry birds with a bit more stuff going on, then go ahead, its well made for that.

If you had hoped for anything more, such as rolling a 20 sided die or any die, making choices with saving roles, etc, this is not that game. Its not even a card game, so dont expect that either.

So im not saying its bad, im saying its not anything special and i dont reccomend mediocrity. Ill keep playing till im fed up, just to make sure i didnt jump the gun, but i doubt i did.

reviewText:
I wanna recommend this game... but no. I fail to see what makes it worthy with the other games on steam. The baordgame style is enjoyable, the tutorial is thorough (even if it does a bit much of the hand holding). It fails in it's disguise of of free to play. Sure you can play for free but it quickly points out the things you won't get unless you pay. Even still, I don't have a problem with this system. You  get to play and see if you like it and just not buy if you don't find it enjoyable. What I have a problem with is the insane price jump for simple stuff. For $19.99 you get the actual game plus 100 pizza (in-game premium currency). That's crap when considering the game isn't worth $20- No voice-overs just odd sound effects for dialog pop-ups, no live action, pretty basic boardgame style play with nothing all that new brought to the table, and certainly nothing compelling for a $20 game and this title has the nerve to push for a monthly fee (that is optional but still thats some bs).

I'm a frugal steam gamer. Thanks to steam sales, I've been able to enjoy amazing titles with little more than $20 (I tend to burn too much of that on beer and use the change for videogames :-() in my pocket at any given time. But this game will never compete with those deals (most recently Depth >$10 for a full game and crap my pants fun!). The price for pizza is between $4.99 to like $98.00 (150 and 3,800 slices respectfully)! That's insane! This can be used for premium gear as the game quickly points out 3.5 hours in. I have mobile games that are more cost effective than this with better graphics and sound.

Short and simple is this, if this game advertised itself as a $20 FULL game on steam it wouldn't get a 2nd look but I'd at least have more respect for it. There are waaaaay too many titles (especially the random badasses that go on 80-90% sales for no damn reason other than that the sun came up that day)  it can't compete with with at the same relative cost. This game hides it's price tag until play it and when it shows itself it is a bloated mess of cost. I would never recommend this game to my friends because with this cost structure they'd laugh at me, tell me to play Path of Exile, and to take note of how a real free to play game is suppose to be setup. Woof!

reviewText:
I gave it a shot free-to-play, trying to see why it had such good ratings on Metacritic.  I played for about 6 hours across 2 days and so far it's like watching corn grow, when it's not trying to sell me something...which is EVERY single time I play.

Cards are linked together in items, often include negatives, are repetitive, and do no damage to speak of.   Having the cards linked to items seriously hampers the deck-building aspects of the game.

The dungeon playboards are extremely repetitive and having to repeat them to level another character is very tedious.

Having to join a club" to get additional loot items is also ludicrous.  I also note that more often than not the better items wind up being in the "club" slot.

If you're into watching grass grow
recommended: and restrictive repetitive cards then you might like it
hoursPlayed: but I'd advise everyone to step away from this one."

reviewText:
This game has weird mechanics that leave you saying 'Oh come the ♥♥♥♥ on' way to many times, especially the fact that you can't move your characters without a move card. As you are only likely to get 1 move card per draw for the character, you will often find yourself stuck in the same position as enemies just walk away from you and you are unable to follow having used up your move card and you don't get new cards until you end your turn. This becomes very annoying when enemies start cover the floor with damage over time spells.

The lack of the ability to move your characters around without a card to move is really, really annoying. Pure and simple. The fact that the enemy's constantly move away from you makes it even more annoying. The fact that some enemies make standing still punishment for you even even more annoying.

Of course all your attacks also come in the form of cards. You cannot reuse them. You can have a character use up his 1-2 attacks and not really be able to do anything against the enemies around him unless you end the turn to redraw cards. Half of the games I played featured my dwarf sitting there doing nothing while being attacked simply because I wanted to use my other characters.

I cannot stant the mechanics. Maybe if you only controlled 1 character at a time it would be more workable, but having your party stand around and do nothing but get hit while you're moving your mage around to do something, then having them hit again as you launch off a couple spells without doing much of anything isn't an enjoyable system.

I do not recommend this game.

reviewText:
I have fully enjoyed my time playing this game thus far and, for a sound investment of $0, it's one of my cheaper experiences. The combat flows extraordinarily well and is pretty easy to understand.

However, this game does come with some notable flaws: Card draw and deck size. There are a few cantrips scattered throughout what I've seen so far, some even going so far as to allow you to take another action after drawing the card. These lack of cantrips can seriously drag a game on or even completly screw an attempt over. You can continue to draw only movement cards, or armor cards, or block cards. This gets highly frustrating, especially when it happens two, three, or even four rounds in a row. Being able to opt into slimming your deck size down might help this a little bit. Perhaps this is handled later on down the line and I just haven't gotten to it.

On the other hand, it does have some great mechanics. Your choice of cards (or, rather, items which have cards attached to them) plays out as a big Risk vs. Reward" when comparing cards from a single tier. Do you want an armor that has three "Armor 1. Keep."s
date: or one that has one "Armor 1. Keep."
voteText: the usage of monster groups that use a card pool is a very clever idea that I for one would never have considered; it helps to balance out combat between 3 player characters and many more enemies without bogging down combat by making groups move at once.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: it's an awesome game. Highly recommend it."

reviewText:
Card Hunter is one of the best co-op turn-based strategy games in existence. Enough said there.

Given there's no true pay to win or catchup mechanisms, however, PvP tends to be won by the guy who's been around the longest. Since this PvP is what most would consider the endgame, this means that the game eats itself as it ages.

Attempts have been made at making the game more evangelical. Leagues, particularly limited format ones, are incredible, and maps you create can be added to the game in the Mauve Manticore dungeons, which are finally firing once per month like they stated when they first devised the idea. Further, Aloyzo's Arsenal allows players to submit custom items which can be added to the game.

The issue here is that none of their evangelical work gets to the heart of the problem, which is that their loot design denies new players the ability to try entire categories of strategies - burst mage and vampire priest being the worst offenders - for their first months of playtime. And if a set of ranked maps favors these old-player builds for that month, well, Card Hunter likely has lower new player retention that month.

Basically, the game needs to ensure that there's no exclusivity. Stay to win is almost as bad as pay to win.

Still, play the PvE. It's incredible, and you'll have a blast.

reviewText: Fantastic, balanced, and addictive.  Great humor and gameplay. Challenging encounters, fun tactical battles, and just a good time. I'm shocked this is free. There's a whole micro-transaction thing (which in general makes me sick), but at least they aren't bombarding you with the concept or creating impossible situations that require the microtransactions. I like the game so much that I was tempted to pursue the microtransactions just to give props to the designers. I didn't. I settled for writing a positive review.

reviewText:
This is a pretty addictive game and enjoyable, don’t expect the depth and richness of something like magic as it’s simpler than that but that’s part of the charm.

IMHO I wouldn't say it's a pay-to-win the reason being the currency, being pizza and gold, can be earned through the single player campaign. The only advantages of paying include:

> Getting more items – You get more items during the campaign, there are treasure hunt adventures that can get you more items, and you can get more gold to get more items.

> Cosmetic – You can get additional avatars

> League games – You can join multiplayer leagues games, and if you win you can actually get gold, pizza and items anyway.

This basically means that you can get items faster, but you can always get items playing the FREE multiplayer 1v1 anyway, and that you can play the league games which are enjoyable. Overall it’s worth a go.

reviewText:
Okay. so the trailer makes this game look really dumb.

In all reality though, this game is absolutely AMAZING.
Best i can describe it is DnD with card based actions.
Its got some really good humor, and can actually offer a pretty good ammount of challenge.
I havent ♥♥♥♥ed with any of the real world money shops, so i couldnt say if its P2W or not.

Typical gameplay: You are put into an adventure / quest, and you have to use strategy and your cards to defeat the enemies. To get new cards, after every battle you get loot, which take the form of items to equip to your characters. Each item offers a new set of cards, which increases strategical aspects. theres actually even co-op, and its a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of fun! theres also PvP, and ranked PvP, but i havent ♥♥♥♥ed with that, im not a PvP kinda person.



all in all, if you are on this page, and like humorous dnd-esque games, ignore the trailer. try this out. its free, and a fairly small download. what is there to lose, other than a few hours xD?

reviewText: A very fun game.  The only downside is that hands each round are completely random from your deck, so it is possible to have a completely useless hand that you dont need.  But it is balanced out considering enemies seem to suffer from the same problem.  This game is not pay to win and the prices are very reasonable for unlocked content.  There is no real plot,  each mission has its own mini story.  The dialogue is humorious and seems to cater to people who play allot of table top role playing games.  You get to choose 3 classes and 3 races.  The race you pick determines the mobility and hp of your character.  As for the classes all 3 of them have thier advantages and disadvantages.  The cards you get for each character is determined by the items you equip.  Finding and grinding for good items is at the core of the gameplay.

reviewText:
An amazing little turn-based tactical strategy game with an old school fantasy RPG flavor.  Position your adventurers on a grid map and do battle with monsters using the spells and fighting techniques represented by cards that your adventurers get from the equipment you choose to equip them with.

It has a decent competative MOBA multiplayer as well as a 2-3 player co-op campaign.
The purple prose of the modules provokes just the right amount of nostalgia to invoke OG Dungeons and Dragons.
The competative balance ebbs and flows with each expansion, but is generally pretty good.
The difficulty of the singleplayer/coop campaign varies WILDLY depending on the specific scenerio, any handycaps you may choose to apply, and how you spec your toons.
Expansions/DLC are fun and flavorful if somewhat short and occationally punishingly hard.

Overall a very nicely designed TSG with a good deal of depth and a strong competitive following.  Can be a little hard even for a vetern of the genre in places, the campaign does get stale after a while, and it can be frustrating to grind for a single high level item among the multitude of random drops, but these complaints pale in comparison to the game's many charms.

reviewText:
Highly recomend this game if you like RPG/tactical/fantasy/card game.  So if you fit into that niche this game is for you.  And it's free.  Yes you can spend $$$ and buy gold or pizzas which are used to but extra items/unlock extra quests or club memberships (which get you extra loot items), but you don't need too at all.  The game can be played without spending a penny,shilling or whatever you have, and still very fun.  I actually bought one the AotA pack just because I wanted to support the devs for all the fun I have had with this game and help them expand it and continue on improving it.  Or maybe just feed them or put a roof over their heads etc.
I spent 6 hrs on this game when I first started and many more before I purchased the extra pack.  I didn't play this before it was on steam and now I miss not knowing about it from previous edition.  It plays like a RPG where you choose your characters and then select quests (or mini modules like old school Dungeons and Dragons) then it turns into a tactical board game with cards attatched to each of you characters to use during the battle.  Your cards are determined by what items/weapons/armor etc. you give your character and their class and race.  Very easy to pick up but mastering your items, cards, and using your turns will take some experience.  You may have to exchange items per each battle, sometimes losing badly to learn how each part of the module works and enimies you fight.
Art work is fantastic, bringing me back to the 80's with the old D&D module artwork and style.  Very nice dialoge and narrations during play and some good comedy thrown in to boot.  Try it out, you can't really lose it's free for petes sake.  Hats off to a great game and as of so far I've seen a fantastic dev team working hard to update and keep the game running even after a large influx of players thanks to Steam.  Haven't played the multiplayer as of yet but will soon enough as friends play this too, will update my review when I get there.
Only downside I can pick out right now is you can't play offline.  You have to connect to the games servers to play even single player, so if your offline or the servers are you can't seem to play.  Not a terrible problem since once again it is free but the only negative I can say about this great game.

This game is worth the hour of gameplay and is free so why not waste a hour of your life!
4/10

reviewText: If you liked playing Banner Saga, then this game is pretty similar to it. This is a turn-based card strategy game. You form up three characters as a party to complete the campaigns and earn items in each battles. Even though this game has pay-to-win features and also memberships, but it hasn't affect much of the gameplay. You too can earn pizzas (cash currency) in certain rounds. You can either play it in a single player, where you command three characters. Or in a cooperative-gameplay, where three humans players control one character each. The campaign can seem rather boring as you get deeper into the jungle, as you need certain strategy in order to complete the round. Nevertheless this card game fuses together with item looting lets users to configure and mix-match their character abilities. The tutorial has been very helpful and witty at times, with an amateur player joking with the game master.\n\nFor network connectivity, this game is pretty stable. Suitable for Asian players too, however it maybe hard to matchmake with co-op players due to the timezones.

reviewText:
I will just make a brief review here.

Card Hunter is like a board game, but not your ordinary board game. It's quite simple and casual but still 'deep' enough for people who are not really into casual stuff.

The things I like from this game are:
1. It has a unique system that a character's deck is built from whatever equipments the character has.
2. RPG element, characters can be levelled up.
3. All characters are free to recruit from the first level. If you feel that you have picked a character that does not fit your style of play, just go recruit another one.
4. You can name your character
5. You can play alone or together with your friends, no problem.
6. The artwork is good, I like it
7. It's FREE!! Why are you hesitating??

Other things (not bad, not good, but maybe you might want to know):
1. Costume/cosmetic is only represented by the character token. Real money is needed for these character tokens, they are not cheap but not really important either.
2. Everytime you cleared a battle in campaign mode, you will get loots. There will be an extra loot on each post-battle screen, you could only get that random extra loot if you're some kind of a premium member (this involves real money). The extra random items are not always good.
3. There are also some storylines/campaigns which need your money to be able to be unlocked.
4. Is this P2W? So far I can't give you that answer yet because I only play on the co-op mode :P

I rarely engage in the PVP mode but so far the single and co-op mode has been fun for me.

reviewText:
I was a little unsure at first about a union of D&D and cards.

Never have I been happier to be wrong.  This game is exactly what I didn't know I had been looking for.

The game perfectly and seamlessly blends the tabletop feeling of dungeons and dragons, with the amazing combat system this game has created.  The AI is somewhat intelligent - I'm still pre level 10 - and while I wish it was a little more challenging in terms of the enemy health and skills.

In terms of abilities, I would like to see a larger pool of abilities, and less of the repeats from weapon to weapon.  Once again though, I am still pre level 10, so it may change down the road.

Fast paced, fairly good storyline so far (the younger brother of a DM attempting to DM for the first time) makes for a few laughs every now and then.

i would very much reccomend this game to anyone, familiar or not with the tabletop gaming world.

10/10

reviewText:
I have fully enjoyed my time playing this game thus far and, for a sound investment of $0, it's one of my cheaper experiences. The combat flows extraordinarily well and is pretty easy to understand.

However, this game does come with some notable flaws: Card draw and deck size. There are a few cantrips scattered throughout what I've seen so far, some even going so far as to allow you to take another action after drawing the card. These lack of cantrips can seriously drag a game on or even completly screw an attempt over. You can continue to draw only movement cards, or armor cards, or block cards. This gets highly frustrating, especially when it happens two, three, or even four rounds in a row. Being able to opt into slimming your deck size down might help this a little bit. Perhaps this is handled later on down the line and I just haven't gotten to it.

On the other hand, it does have some great mechanics. Your choice of cards (or, rather, items which have cards attached to them) plays out as a big Risk vs. Reward" when comparing cards from a single tier. Do you want an armor that has three "Armor 1. Keep."s
date: or one that has one "Armor 1. Keep."
voteText: the usage of monster groups that use a card pool is a very clever idea that I for one would never have considered; it helps to balance out combat between 3 player characters and many more enemies without bogging down combat by making groups move at once.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: it's an awesome game. Highly recommend it."

reviewText:
This is probably the only review I have written.

This game is pretty great! I grew up playing tabletop dungeons and dragons among many other systems. This is a simple easy to use game that emulates the gaming experience of a tabletop RPG game using cards, amor pieces that translate to attacks and abilities and an almost board game style layout with floor tiles you travel along as you play. Its like combining a card battle with a stradegy turn based game with the dungeons and dragons (Medieval) setting and feel (its actually more generic then D&D but I figured it would be the easiest trigger word description).

You have a quarky new DM (Dungeon Master) that narrates as you progress by describing the scene; you and enemies you encounter, as well as a cast of other characters that chime in periodically, like the pizza delivery girl, his brother the veteran and cruel DM and his mom.

Overall Im giving this a good review because it was free, easy to use yet still challanging and very well done. Ive been playing it non-stop since I bought it and still have yet to complete it. You finish one dungeon, 3 more pop up.  You can have multiple characters including multiplayer ones. The roster is pretty basic: Warrior, Cleric, Mage, but you can mix them up by buying new characters at the tavern, change their appearance and buy them new weapons, armor and magical items which totally customize the game play!

reviewText:
Strikes a surprisingly good balance of fun vs profit for a pay2win game.

The single player campaign is well tuned and will leave you wanting more, which is where the independently purchasable modules come in. Since you're purchasing actual content, it doesn't leave you feeling sullied when you hand over the cash, even if the individual purchases ultimately add up to the cost of a AAA game.

The power token system ensures that even very early game loot will have a place in your end-game party builds. Higher level gear requires more and more tokens, you'll never possess enough tokens that you can deck your character entirely in high level gear. It's a clever idea, and well implemented.

I haven't touched the multiplayer, but this is where, I imagine, the pay2win issues are a little more at the forefront. There are no item rarity restrictions, and legenday / rare items are a very powerful and central part of many pvp builds.

Protip: When starting out, you'll be given pizza to spend on costumes and chests. You don't have to do so. Spend that pizza on card hunter club membership instead, it will make playing the campaign much more enjoyable.

reviewText:
Tl;dr at the boottom

What it is : Card hunter is a tactical tabletop simulator focused on combat with Rpg elements sprinkled on top of it.

How does it play out : You control an adventuring band of 3 heros ready to face all the dangers the land of cardhuntria has to offer. Your character's equipped gear determine the skills ( cards ) that can be used in battle, those skills ranges from moving cards to blocking cards to healing to utility and attack cards with merged cards that allow two actions i.e( attack and move ) . Said gear can be equipped in slots that you gain when you level up your characters. That gear is sperated into 5 catagories ( common, uncommon , rare, Epic and legendary ) with the rarer varity gaining you powerful skills, said gear is also further seperated into gear that require power tokens - which you gain from leveling up - power tokens are also seperated into minor and major power tokens, they serve no purpose but as a prequiste to equiping gear.

Is it P2W : No, it is not. Spending money on the game yields you cosmetics and extra content, represented in more campaign modes i.e. ( citadel in the sky, attack of the artifacts) and treasure hunts that yields you a single Epic class gear.

Is it fun : Extremely.

Does have any flaws : Yes. As with all fun games you want more. I would have liked if it had more classes ( rogues , scouts..etc. ), out of combat focus even if it was just yes or no choices and steam work shop support for player created campaigns.

Verdict : Very fun game to play with amazing content to match 8/10

Tl;dr : Xcom meets D&D in a weird card game like manner , easy to play hard to master, free to play , turn based , amazing content , paying unlocks more amazing content , wish it had more things to do other than combat.

reviewText:
This is a great game that does F2P right. The game is a blend of turn based Dungeons & Dragons style battles with a collectible card game. Blue Manchu has managed to combine the two types of game quite well. Each piece of equipment you attach to a character has a set of cards associated with it. This allows the player to quickly change their deck without going through and micromanaging every single card. In battle, the cards are drawn randomly from the pool each character has and are used to take actions. Movement, healing, attacking, and other status effects are all invoked by cards. This makes battles dynamic, interesting, and random.

There is quite a bit of content for free but the game can get a bit grindy at higher levels. Several expansion modules have been released that can be purchased in game. There are also a few other perks that can be purchased, such as an increase in loot drops and additional character images. None of this is necessary to enjoy the game and there is plenty to do without paying a dime. Blue Manchu has balanced the difficult task of having a free game that is not pay to win and is worth paying a few dollars for for players who really enjoy it. I would recommend getting the additional modules, as they are pretty fun and help level up a bit quicker.

I first played this game when it first came out so my Steam playtime doesn't represent my full playtime. I had taken a break from it and saw that it was added to Steam. With the Steam release is the new co-op feature. This allows a person to each control a character and take turns. This has been a lot of fun with friends and adds another element to the game since it requires focusing on a single character rather than the whole team.

I would highly recommend this game for RPG and CCG fans. The two genres are blended perfectly to create a unique and engaging experience. There's nothing else really like it.

reviewText:
This is one of the very few games I had to quit cold turkey. Other such games include Diablo II and League of Legends.

So you know you're in good company.

This game gives you a party of three heroes, a bunch of tactical turn-based missions (a la X-Com), a tongue-in-cheek campaign, a pvp mode, and way too much loot to customize your dudes and dudettes.

It's free to play, but the monetization is fair, and you don't have to pay anything to play. People who pay get 4 loot items instead of 3 at the end of every mission, and it's not that big a deal. Overall this game scores three stars out of three: it has swords, elves and pvp.
And yes, you can equip swords on your elves to hack other people up.

Come on in, the water is fine.

reviewText: This game is so much fun. It's a board game that uses card game mechanics for combat, the cards in your deck are set by the equipment your characters have. The combat is in small 5 to 10 (usually) minute chunks so you can invest as much or as little time per session as you want. It's also an homage to old school D&D, with many of the chapters fashioned after classic modules. It is free with a P2P element, but (at least initially) it isn't as in your face as a lot of games are. Some people won't like paying the approximately $10-$12 to unlock content (a special dungeons pack and 2 expansions as of this writing each cost around that price) but it seems like there is enough content even without that. Did I mention there is PvP and multiplayer co-op? If you like strategy board games, card games, or old school D&D, you will love this game. Highest recommendation.

reviewText: OLD SCHOOL FUN
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is a bit of a mixed bag, but not for the reasons you'd think.

As a freemium title, you'd expect it to be rife with pay-to-have-fun features and short on content. It is neither of those things. What you get instead is a fun little throwback to old school AD&D, complete with a perfect mimicry of the art and writing styles of that era of game design. And my god, it even plays like old DnD - just a simplified, reasonable version, dressed up with some crunchy deck-building mechanics. It's accessible, it's charming, and above all it's fun. It's a gem of a game.

So, why is Card Hunter a mixed bag?

The answer to that is Gary and Melvin.

Campaign mode in Card Hunter is basically a three-character story. Gary is your GM, Melvin is his older brother, and then there's a girl from a pizza place. The pizza girl is totally fine as a character. Gary and Melvin make me writhe in my chair.

Imagine, if you will, a hobby shop. Imagine this hobby shop is in a crappy part of your city. Imagine its windows are so heavily plastered with comics and action figure ads from the 1970, all of which are faded and peeling and stuck on with tape. Imagine that you've gone inside this store, wrinkling your noise at the powerful funk of old books and spilled snackfood that fills the cramped, dirty space within. Imagine there's only one customer, fat and unwashed, paging idly through Bikini Mail Magazine. And now imagine that behind the cracked, ancient counter, lounging in a pool of his own adipose folds, is a forty-something man in a pit-stained old t-shirt and sweatpants, hyucking softly to himself as he optimizes his WoW build on his laptop.

Now imagine you've collapsed that entire experience into a single person. That person is Melvin.

Gary is not much better.

Thanks to Gary and Melvin, Card Hunter is a wild roller coaster of highs and lows. You'll fight a sharkbear, and that'll be pretty cool. Then Gary will say something cringing and miserable and you'll want to claw your own eyes out. You'll perservere, though, and get to see some righteous module art about cannibal yetis living in a blizzard. And then Melvin will open his mouth and you'll dream about just punching him. Punching him until he stops moving. Punching him FOREVER.

I've never seen a game ooze social awkwardness like this one, and it's a damn shame, because everything else about it is great. The devs clearly are familiar with old school DnD. They get what tabletop culture used to be like.

And then they choose to make the faces of Card Hunter a distillation of all the worst parts of the people who play the hobby.

Maybe they hate themselves?

reviewText: Card Hunter is a fun game and will give you a good 2-4 weeks of game play for no pay, unless you binge it--then you won't get as much out of it. Meh, your mileage may vary. I plateaued after a week, so take that for what it's worth. What's it like? Well, for an old guy like me, it's a pleasant bit of nostalgia. For younger players, it's a throwback to the old D&D tabletop games of well, my childhood--late 70's - early 80's, though a lot of the genre trappings of late 80's - late 90's are present. Let me tone it down a bit and explain.\n\nYou get three generic characters with basic item slots. Pick an elf, dwarf, or human for each, and pick a warrior, mage, cleric for each. Each item slot grants access to certain cards you will play in battle. Adventuring leads to better gear which grants better powers. reviewText:
Don't get me wrong it's a nice concept, a simplified version of DnD without the hastle of trying to learn how to build characters through an ocean of content. But the way it is now some things need to change. Most situations feel like they need to be handled by more then 3 team members and the game overwhelms you in later missions with large amounts of NPCs that are both small damage and large damage leaning more in the favor of large damage enemies. Usually ending with you trying to prioritize the high damage enemies but taking too much damage or losses to consider the exchanges worth while.

Pros:

Simple:
Easy to learn, your abilities are based on the equipment you have, enemies aren't overcomplicated time bombs you don't want to go near, races are genericly balanced, and classes have designated equips.
Great Fun with Friends:
Co-op with friends is a blast, makes everything twice as fun.
Comedic Writing:
The game can be funny at times making it feel more worthwile to play through the campaign
Equiment:
Easy to understand, a little hard to obtain without grinding lower level missions, and equipment is balanced with major and minor power tokens so you aren't a complete god against the AI.
Easy to Change:
You don't have to stick to one party, you can buy new party members for a low cost of ingame currency and interchange party members at any time to fit your play style.

Cons:

Classes aren't what they seem to be:
The classes can be built one of two ways, either all aggression or complete support roles. There are no effective in betweens because you're either losing out on damage or don't help the other members in your team.
Wizards aren't at all DPS, most spells at a wizard's disposal are weak or are easily snuffed out by enemy armors/blocks. Also most beginning damage spells are close range that deal no damage, meaning you have to sit in damage range just to do damage and this follows you well into mid game depending on your load out. The wizards that can control spells that manipulate the battlefield have no damage what so ever.
Priests are squishy supports that can't stay in combat very long for the same reason, they do almost no damage. With the all aggression priests they have almost no support and once again can't stay in combat because they can't take a hit.
Warriors are either high damage DPS with no range or medium DPS with range. Warriors aren't tanks either considering most NPCs will just chip off 50% or more of your member's HP without even trying. Warriors either move into range and then have the target immediatly move out of range afterwards or do little to no damage with longer range attacks.
Equipment:
It will screw you again and again, most equipment is either okay but nothing substantial. Anything that's good either has terrible draw backs from using them or require so many power tokens you can't use anything else that's good until you're high level. Your equipment is determind by RNG so you might just get a bunch of stuff for warriors or priests, but get nothing for your mage. Essentially making that unit completly worthless unless you do a grindfest or buy new overpriced equipment. Main issues with equipment is you're forced to use low level equipment even though your other gear is leagues ahead of it and it's mainly useless in your missions. There isn't any scaling in gear level, you have your low level gear that doesn't require power tokens, mid range gear that requires minor power tokens, and high grade gear that requires either major power tokens or both major and minor power tokens. At max level team members, you only get 4 major power tokens and 4 minor tower tokens. Which you have to try and prioritize certain equipment slots over others, making you weak extremely weak in one department and strong in another. The Warrior class has 9 equipment slots, Mage 10 slots, and Priests with 10 slots. With most late game gear using 2 major power tokens you're already missing half your stock for only one equipment item. So now you're stuck trying to build for pure DPS or pure support for certain classes. There is no effective inbetween for both offensive and defensive builds, they both work against each other and flood your hand with either or, not a mixture of both.
Gold/Shop:
Making gold is stupidly hard uphill battle of RNG and selling extra equipment for almost nothing to buy new equipment. To be actually able to sell back items you don't use you need to get a renown of 7, probably about 8 or so campaign missions. Their main reason in doing this is to have players build a good amount of equipment before going and blindly selling off equipment they aren't using. Main issue with this is once you get to sell items they aren't worth much of anything unless it's rare or legendary equipment which still sells for a crappy amount of gold. Common equipment is usually worth around one to two gold, where rare and legendary sell for around 50 to 100 gold. Selling one legendary piece of equipment gets you enough gold to buy one mediocre item from the shop. Your main way of making gold is selling common extras of equipment and cheap treasure with your occasional semi-precious treasure.
NPCs and RNG are jerks:
NPCs won't move unless you do most of time making it hard to determine how to plan for a situation, most times the NPCs seem to be well aware of what you possess in your hand. NPCs seem to just get cards that undermine everything you try to do. They either have so much armor and block you can't do anything or their rolls against you and for themselves feel rigged in their favor most of the time. Most of their saving rolls are 4+ and they seem to get the rolls they need flawlessly at most points in time. My armors and blocks have a saving roll of 2 or better and I still end up failing them 90% of the time.
Races:
The different races don't work well together at all. Dwarves are all tank but no movement which makes them pair terribly with humans and elves because they just leave them behind in the dust. If you're going to play with a dwarf you might as well make the rest of your party dwarves and play defensivly. The only good time to have one dwarf is as a mage because they don't have to be front line. Humans are a balance of both health and movement making them your go tos for optional play styles and are able to switch between aggressive and passive play styles. Elves are all mobility with no health making them get in and out characters or complete avoidance characters. You're not staying in combat with elves, you're either dashing in to do a little damage then dashing out or attacking from afar. Elves don't pair well with other races because they just leave the other races behind and end up over extending themselves.
Little to no hand manipulation:
There are barely any card draws and some of them punish you for trying to get new cards that are better for the situation. There is little to no enemy hand manipulation unless you can specificly build for it and land the ability through the NPC's/Player's saving roles. So far the only enemy hand manipulation cards I have seen remove their oldest block or all of them or remove armor cards. Enemy NPC's will most likely do this to themselves before you even know what to use to manipulate their hand.

My current stand point with this game is neutral, I love the concept but hate the way the game is going at the moment. I'm left here to hope they change some of these glaring issues before I loose all interest for a game that punishes players for trying to build for multiple utilities. If you want to play it for fun's sake with friends you'll probably enjoy this game for a few sessions. But if you want to seriously play all the way to the end power to you, because this game is brutal with it's RNG and rolls for saves. To be able to continue to play for me there needs to be a serious rebalance with how classes work, how card draw works, and how the rolls/RNG work.

reviewText: I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who grew up playing Dungeons and Dragon or who enjoys tactical board games. The art direction is perfectly suited for the medium and every card, icon, and character is easy to comprehend. The adventures are cleverly written to evoke the classic D&D style with a subtle sense of humor. From a gameplay standpoint, Card Hunter scratches that itch for meaningful descisions with the random card elements. By equipping different items before each battle, you can stack your deck with specific cards more suited to overcome the challenges. This will be essential to be able to continue as this game is quite challenging and most maps will require careful turn-by-turn planning and a bit of luck to be able to win. Don't hesitate to re-equip or shop for new items if the enemies are immune to a damage type or have a gimick attack.\n\nAs a free game it scores major points for not including any obnoxious elements like a limitation on play. The cash shop currency is optional and you can complete the singleplayer adventures with the default rewards. Overall this is easily the best tactical board game available on Steam.

reviewText: This game is amazing! It's a mix of RPG,TCG, and Xcom. If that makes you at all excited then try it out! If not, then try it out anyway! It's Free! I have had so much fun that I decided to pay $20 for the Basic Pack to support the devs. The only con so far is the connectivity issues, and those are already being worked on. I would recommend to play the game with friends. However that doesn't mean that the singleplayer isn't fun, I often will hop in to the singleplayer inbetween Co-Op sessions to level my characters and get more loot. The community is friendly and helpful, and the devs have been friendly (haven't interacted with them myself but a bit of browsing the steam forums for this game proves this). I have yet to be frustrated with this game, even when RNG wasn't with me on the card draws I wasn't raging, I was figuring out how to kit myself better for the situation. Just... Check this game out!!

reviewText:
Nice and fun game, a good time killer.
The game is solid, free, and doesn't have any pay to win mechanics, every equipment/card can be earned by playing.
You can play the entire campaign coop, and it's fun playing with your friends.
The problem in coop is that each one play with one character and if you play with only 1 friend (2 characters total)
you are in disadvantage of lacking one character (each draw one additional card, but...), making the game much harder.
The servers now are currently overloaded facing lags and login queue.

TL;DR: overall is great, a very solid and fun game. worth playing. just need to be patient with server issues. needs some coop balancing
